number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
PresentationLili: Child of Geos tells the story of a young botanist, Lili, set on a quest to the supposedly uninhabited island of Geos as part of a school research project, but as the stories never tell the whole truth until you live them, you will soon find out that the island is actually inhabited by creatures called the Spirits and their creations meant to serve them, the Constructs. It won't be long before your arrival will alert the Spirits as your presence starts to influence the lives of the Constructs and make them question their existence as servants, so you will soon be caught up in the affairs of Geos’ locals. As much of a premise for a serious plot there is, the game chooses tell its story in a satirical way, adding jokes and references to other games every now and then, some which fail to deliver, making the entire story feel irrelevant after you realize most quests are there to fill in the space without an actual outcome in the storyline. As a game that focuses on exploration and the landscape it creates with it, it was disappointing to see how limited that exploration really is; it was exciting to find new items, meet new Constructs and see where else their quests will take me, but after a few minutes you will soon realize that there are only around eight additional sidequests, most which take no longer than ten minutes to complete and as for everything you see in the distance, you will never actually get there.Rating: 6GameplayAs for how the game plays, well it certainly is different from anything you have experienced before, as your main objective is to defeat Spirits by jumping onto their back and picking the flowers that spurt from their heads. This is where the game shows its true nature, as it was originally made for tablets and picking flowers by dragging them with your finger across the screen feels natural and easy, but doing the same thing with a mouse can be a little bit tricky. Using a controller makes the whole thing a little bit easier as you can select the flower you want to pull using the action button, but at the same time it creates another problem, as you can only select from a range of four flowers, mapped to their respective action button, so later on in the game when you'll have to deal with up to eight different flowers, weeds and bombs at the same time, the controller will prove to be more of a burden than a helpful tool. Outside the battle the game works much better, using the keyboard and mouse or the controller to move around, collect flowers, look around for treasures and meet Geos' finest, but then again for an open world experience, there is a really small number of things that you can do outside the main story, which isn't that long either and the first glance at Geos will soon be shattered by exploration limits and the lack of new things to keep you going for longer or distract you from your main objective.Rating: 5GraphicsLooking back at the iOS version of the game, it's clear that the visual upgrade worked out for the best and Lili: Child of Geos looks amazing on PC, but the real beauty when playing the game comes from the art style itself, taking you somewhere between what a gnome village would look like and combining it with a good Pixar movie. The landscapes are simply amazing and as for the characters, even if the Spirits look the same except for their masks, the Constructs each have a unique touch to help you recognize them whenever you see them around Geos. The bad part in all this is that you never get to explore everything that you actually see ahead of you and the five different locations of the island can be completed within minutes as there is nothing else to do besides the main objective and a few chests scattered around.Rating: 8AudioThe soundtrack complements the visual art style, probably not in the best way possible but its better with it there playing the background as you move on than without it. The worst part on the audio side is the absence of voice acting, which is understandable since most mobile titles lack such things, but as a PC port it's hard not to complain about how great the dialogue could've been voiced by the right actors, and on the same note it could've made some of those lame jokes funny just by using the right voice. The sound effects are okay, but since there is a limited number of items and objects that interact with the environment and your character, it will soon feel like a repetitive and monotone experience.Rating: 6ExtrasIt takes around four hours to finish Lili: Child of Geos, which isn't nearly enough to justify a 20€ price tag, and aside from that and a few achievements that you'll miss on your first playthrough there really is nothing else to keep you around, no matter how beautiful the island of Geos is.Rating: 4.5VerdictJudging by the first look, Lili: Child of Geos is beautiful and unique, but in this case the first look is deceiving, as the game won't last more than a few hours and as for the time in which it actually is entertaining, that's probably less than 30 minutes, but if that time is enough for you and you're just looking for a great view, Lili: Child of Geos delivers flawlessly on that side.Rating Overall: 5.9Check out the full review and a lot more about Lili: Child of Geos at http://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=289[/h1]

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												First, let's talk about game length... I heard this was pretty short so I held out for a good sale and finally picked it up for about $4. After almost 3 hours I'm maybe halfway through the game. I figure it should give me at least 5-6 hours of gameplay which is decent for that price but at full price you may want to hold off.Anyway, about the game itself... The characters and the world are totes adorable. You'll find humorous writing, both light and even a little dark, video game references and great art direction. It's a good looking game with it's own style. It's not without flaws, though. The biggest one which may even make it difficult for some people to play this is the barfy mouse-look. I can't even call it mouse acceleration. It's way worse than that. The mouse-look lags way behind and then suddenly snaps into position. It's very awkward and even though I never get motion sickness playing games, this had my stomache rolling sometimes. Also, this game does not allow you set your game up via launcher or main menu. It dumps you into the game right away and you can fiddle with some minor graphics options once you get into it. The game did an adequate job of detecting my hardware and the game ran fine for me but for some others this may end up being a problem. Every game should allow you to configure your settings before rendering more than a menu just for safety's sake.Another minor thing is the lack of voice acting. There are some voice clips, from Lili saying "hi" in 3 or 4 different ways to the other characters having their own little intros/outros to some grunts/barks during combat but aside from that none of the dialog is voiced which is weird since the voice acting that is there isn't bad. It would have been nice for a game this short to be fully voiced, at least the main characters.Overall, though, it's a fun, cute little game involving smashing vases, stealing people's belongings out of thier homes, picking flowers and completing quests in good ol' RPG fashion. Pick it up on sale!

content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												The official description compares this game to Psychonauts, which is fair.  Both games have similar styles in humor (everyone, from Constructs to Spirits to Ominous Fish, has something silly to say to/about you) and design, so if you enjoyed Psychonauts for that aspect (like I did), then you'll enjoy Lili.The gameplay is also fun.  It's an rpg-esque exploration game, interspersed with an interesting little mini game involving ripping flowers out of the backs of malevolent spirits (never thought I'd say that before).  The scenery is gorgeous, definitely encouraging exploration just by being too darn beautiful to want to leave.  And the minigame was kind of addicting; I wanted to keep playing it and beating each of my high scores, yes, but I also wanted to keep playing it because it was fun.My only gripe is that the game felt too short.  A couple more quarters to explore (and maybe a few more outfits to collect) would have scratched that itch.  But hey, maybe in the sequel, right?  ;-)

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												Short but sweet, if I had to summarize in one sentence. A game I think people of all ages could enjoy depending on what they're looking for. For younger kids you have a virtually non-violent, beautiful and funny place to explore. Older audiences might find entertainment in the occasionally dark humor and the game's weird inhabitants. Gameplay-wise Lili: Child of Geos is a very short game. I'd estimate around three hours of casual play. If you're going for collectibles and a perfect ranking against all enemies you may add two or three extra hours of game time. It's not a very challenging game either if you play on easy or medium. During the game you will attempt to "de-flower" spirits walking about the game world. You do this by playing a sort of minigame where you drag and drop flowers and other items off a spirit's head. You can tell this game mechanic was designed for the use of a touchscreen, which isn't too strange as this is a PC remake of a mobile game, but the developers made it work fairly well with a mouse. Depending on your skill, you'll master this part of the game quickly. It does get progressively harder as the game goes on, but it never reaches a level that will really challenge you and have you retry beating a spirit more than a couple of times. I have yet to play the hardest difficulty setting though. There are three settings, of which I played the middle one.Controls are a bit wonky. Camera control takes a bit getting used to. Mouse sensitivity have only four presets which is the part I found the most annoying about the game. Some weird collisions here and there. Otherwise well made. Would I recommend it? Yes, but try to find a bit of gameplay to watch before you decide whether or not to purchase Lili: Child of Geos. It's a game best enjoyed if you go at it with a relaxed attitude. If you're up for exploration and fun in short bursts. It would be easier to recommend this game if it had been cheaper. I don't really think the price suits the length or content of the game. But all in all I'm having fun with it.

Posted: December 31, 2014
												Lili is a decent a reasonably creative collectathon that I can't imagine getting more than 6 hours out of. It's worth picking up on sale, but not for the full price of $20. Pros:- Looks great, especially considering it started on mobile. A lot of that probably comes down to the fact that most levels are cleverly designed to avoid needing to draw more than 20 feet in any direction, but the game does run on Unreal. - Usually clever writing. Not perfect by any means, but it's generally entertaining.- Strong world design. The descriptions comparison to Tim Schafer's work is pretty accurate in the world and character design. - The main mini-game is fun. It involves trying to pick flowers off the head of a spirit as it runs around and sprouts bombs and thorns to make you miss. It's reasonably challenging to win the later rounds with a perfect rating, but you're going to breeze through it if just passing is enough for you. Mileage will vary heavily here. - Lots of hats. Every spirit (52) and most quests (something like 12?) will give you a hat. There are also at least two pets to find, but the costume changes are limited to palette swaps, unfortunately. Cons:- Very limited graphics options. You get a few presets with no descriptions of what any of them actually do. I don't think many people are going to have trouble running the game, but Highest turns on an incredible level of depth of field. I'd have liked to be able to turn that off. - Short. I finished it in 3 hours. That was enough to defeat all 52 spirits (most with 3/3 stars), complete nearly all of the quests, and find around 60-70% of the collectibles. - Controls are a bit wonky. Particularly the camera. Notes:- Achievement hunters beware! Lili has a ton of achievements and *most* are near enough to completable in a sane person's playthrough. Then there's "Break 1,000 vases." I only got to 120 despite making an effort to break any I came across. You could probably get an extra 100 or so by going out of your way to look for them, but the full 1K is going to take some serious grinding. - Trying to play it on a standard touchpad would be a nightmare. - The description compares this to Zelda, but the only similarities I can find are some of the humor, Wind Waker's art direction, and the fact that money is completely and utterly useless in both games. Don't buy it hoping for puzzles or Zelda-like combat.

Posted: June 20, 2015
												Lili: Child of Geos is a nice quirky little game for in between!The game - originally only for mobile devices - convinces with it's pretty visuals and very own charm.Just don't expect "too much" from it for it is very short. Nevertheless I would recommend it, since it is a funny little game to lift your mood and very enjoyable due to its fresh and unique gameplay.

Posted: June 10, 2015
												Even though Lili: Child of Geos might be addressed to a younger audience it really caught me from the first second.The Graphics are bright, atmospheric and joyful, it's so harmonic. There is no violence and there is none needed to make it a good game. It's fun to collect all achievements and explore the island and all the cute and funny characters really catch you from the very beginning.It's also very varying that the heroine is such a casual, everyday girl, I really liked playing her.

Posted: January 4, 2015
												This game is really nice to look at. Very pretty. Lots of plants and stuff.The characters are likeable, the story is pretty decent, and the environment is quite nice.Plus all the humour and video game references, 8/10.Just wait for it to go on sale. 20+ bucks is a bit of a rip.

Posted: September 14, 2014
												This game is beautiful. I love this game. It's obvious that the Devs love this game, and really poured over every detail. Some are saying that it's "light on story" And I'm here to tell you that that's a load of♥♥♥♥♥♥ It's one of those games the story needs to be pieced together, by finding items, talking to NPCs, and completing main quests. So if you're unable to pay attention for 5 seconds, you'll probably miss most of the awesome references and happenings within the game. But if your patient, and play the game the way it's meant to be played (Casually) you will experience the full effects of it. My sister who is a toddler will sit down (something she doesn't do often) and watch me play this game. It is so vibrant, and full of color it can capture the attention of a 2 year old.  Beautiful game, an experience that brought me back to some of my favorite games I used to play on my N64, and GameCube. 8.5/10. P.S: If you scroll up and this game is still on sale for 4$, BUY IT RIGHT NOW ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥IT WHAT'S WRONG WITH YOU! LIKE SELL YOUR CS:GO SKINS OR TRADING CARDS!

												Relax ,Fun exploration, and Fantastic atmosphere.You play as young botanist named Lili who is sent to discover Geos island as a part of her student project.The game is about exploration and meeting. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												There's a lot going on in Lili: Child of Geos.  Too much to slap you with a witty pair of sentences and run away giggling.  So here's some proper paragraphs for you kids as I lead you on a bold coming-of-age adventure where you learn to part with three to five of your dollars but no more than that; an adventure where you learn if great art direction with a bit of humor can make up for some flawed gameplay and a very basic story:You will take control of Lili: a young crossdressing botanist with daddy issues on a quest to "deflower" a population of anthropomorphic gardens.  Okay, okay.  That is only technically true, you cheeky reviewer, you.  It's a very inclusive, cheerfully bright, and quite original game, although the daddy issues still stand.  And in fact they stand in the way of me giving this game an unqualified recommendation.  I'm talking not about Lili the character, but the game itself.  It is so proud of its roots that it spends too much time placing them on display rather than nurturing its uniqueness to blossom into a memorable classic.  Lili brings a lot to the table, but what's ultimately going to keep you playing (or not) are its story, characters, and setting.  Lili: CoG tries to follow the likes of games like Monkey Island by having a story-focused game supported by a strong sense of humor.  The story itself is unchallenging, boiling down to: bad guys are bad guys and it's up to you to put things right.  Bless it, it tries to do more by giving Lili a personal dilemma that comes into conflict with her objectives, but when it comes time for her to choose, there's really no consequence to the choice you make.  Although, I guess we can hand out a gold star for at least letting the player make a choice.   Okay, so the story is middling, what does this have to do with that whole roots/blossoming/flower-metaphors-for-a-game-about-flowers  line you were banging on about?  Well, presumably if the story is lacking, it could be supported by its humor.  And the game has some wonderfully funny moments.  Unfortunately, you might just stop playing before you ever get to them.  A lot of the jokes in the first areas of the game you explore take the form of references to other games and the games industry, and praise toward the games that inspired Lili.  And, as many of us know, references aren't really jokes, especially since you have to have a pretty broad knowledge of games to appreciate most of them.  I did get a grin or two out of these, but it wasn't until the second half of the game when the earnest chuckles came; when Lili started being Lili instead of her various daddies' girl.I know anybody reading the length of this review is probably ready with their metaphorical throwing produce if I don't get to talking about the gameplay soon, but this is a very hippy-dippy, rainbow colored, mostly non-violent, interactive experience and there's a bit more to be said.  This game.  Is.  Beautiful.  No, really, it is.  The birds even poop rainbows!!!  It could sell itself alone on its art direction (it's a shame it comes a bit too close to doing that).  Without an army of artists and polygons, Lili creates a vivid, bright, painterly world that is going to stay good looking for decades.  The environments feel very open, engaging, and wholely Lili's own.  Lili is a realistically proportioned human exploring a luminous world populated by wooden robots and grim-looking masked spirits none of which are short on personality.  It's got a bit of a Miyazaki vibe to it, but it's ultimately Lili's own world, and it's truly charming.  Right, gameplay.  In Lili, you chase down spirits, jump onto their backs, and try to yank off the flowers that sprout up with your mouse, while avoiding hazards that threaten to knock you off and let the spirit escape: interesting, arcadey, surprisingly challenging as the difficulty ramps up.  It's refreshingly different from many other adventure/action/RPG hybrids that will mostly have you swinging a sword around at the things you want maimed.  It isn't quite perfect, though.  It works okay with mouse controls, but does feel imprecise at times and can get a bit frustrating when the things you want appear in dense clusters of hazards.  It seems designed with touch screens in mind, but I only used the mouse, so I can't comment on that implementation.  The RPG elements, especially, seem misguided.  Upgrades are handed out at odd intervals and never seem essential, especially with items providing boosts that don't so much compliment your skills in running fast, stealth, and hanging onto enemies, as render them completely irrelevant.  The increments from leveling up and getting items aren't entirely unnoticeable, but the RPG elements could have gotten cut and nothing would have been lost.  In fact, the stealth aspect to the game is really non-existant.  You won't have to worry about things like which way the enemy is facing, what cover you place yourself behind, or the amount of lighting on you.  Stealth is merely a stat that determines how close you can get before the enemy automatically notices you.  If stealth games really turn you on, as they do me, just know that this isn't a stealth game, but a perfectly fine arcadey affair.  And, you know, you can just have a stealth-sandwhich and be invisible, so why the stats at all? I'll admit, I only played the game on normal difficulty.  The game does have easy and hard settings, but as an adult with adequate reflexes, I found Lili to be fairly easy to get through, but challenging to get through well (you are scored for each enemy you face and given a small reward in the form of a mask for doing well).  I'd say that makes it ideal, but then, I'm not sure exactly who this game was made for.  The simple saccharine story and visuals make it seem like a casual game for parents to play with their children, though I think even with an easy setting, reflex challenges might prove inherently difficult for younger kids.  But if it's just meant to appeal to the children of the 90s, now present day indie gamers, the difficulty is on the ball in terms of gameplay.  That audience will probably find the story a bit too easy, however (unless you want to get meta and compare Lili - the character's - struggle living in her father's shadow to Lili - the game's - struggle to emerge from the shadow of monumental games like a terribly clever gamer whose review will be super influential).So who is Lili for?  Well, me, I guess.  I mostly enjoyed it and I recommend it if you think the strengths I've just beamed into your head outweigh the bits that are mediocre - and those bits are just mediocre, never really bad.

Posted: December 16, 2014
												Lili is a fairly good port of what I believe at one point to have been an ipad game.Initially, it struck me as not too good because it does suffer from invisible wall syndrome. However, I kept playing and got quite into it, the game is actually pretty good on the exploration and "questing" front, even if it doesn't have a massive map. I did find that the game was rather heavy on the "collecting items" front.Music is very good, and the sound bites work well to enhance the text which makes up the dialogue as there are are no full-text voices. The dialogue in this game has lots of humour, and the story it tells is good.The Graphics are very nice, cartooney not photorealistic. The design of the maps in the world are likewise very well done.I did encounter a bug that prevented the in-game cursor from loading, but this was easily fixed by switching resolutions in-game. The game is listed as having full controller support, but you shouldn't be playing with a controller. It is simply not suited to this.Overall, while it isn't the most amazing game out there, it does provide for a fun game that you can probably get through in an afternoon, if you have one free. I will say that if you're after a heavy RPG, don’t go for this. But if you want to buy this for a more easy-going RPG, or one suited to children, then this is a good choice.

Posted: December 25, 2014
												A friend bought me this game during the sale, but its charm alone is worth the MSRP of $20. I thought I would play for like 10 minutes just to try the game out but a little more then an hour had past before I finally shut it off.  It is a fun explorative game, down the lines of similar platformers like Zelda or Dark Cloud.  Except this game has a child like charm attached to it, so you won't find any swords or any weapons for that matter.  Even bombs are fairly harmless and the worst you'll be doing in the game is picking flowers off of evil spirits.  Its a very zen like experience to gameplay.There are tons of characters with their own charms, and the graphics play their role dutifully.  If you're looking for a deep story look elsewhere but if not and can open your heart to a game that has a story closer to a childrens movie you will find alot of enjoyment.  Talking to NPC's and admiring the little details in every scene.

Posted: October 4, 2014
												This game is great. It's an adventure focused on exploration and it contains a few RPG elements. It makes fun of videogames and clichés, it has "fighting" mechanics I've never seen before and it presents some of the weirdest NPCs you'll ever meet.Pro:+ beautiful visuals+ great soundtrack+ innovative gameplay+ good level design+ lots of humor+ many collectibles+ the story is nice and it fits to the game...Contra:- ...but it's very short- playing on after the credits isn't very exciting- it isn't a good game for achievement hunters

Posted: June 5, 2015
												Do you crave an adventure game with a female protagonist, but Lara Crofts breast size intimidate you? Do you yearn for a graphically pleasing game like Zelda, but the puzzles and game mechanics too much for your pretty little face? Then "Lili: Child of Geos" will satisfy all your needs. Get it, Enjoy it, and tell Gaben that Fly sent you.

Fun characters and dialogue         Interesting challengesCons: short          repetitiousI got this during a steam sale and believe it was worth the price. Can't say it would be for normal price. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												Lili: Child of Geos is a very peculiar and unique game. It is a game that children and adults (channel your inner child adults!) can play and enjoy.Graphics: When the graphics are set on 'Fantastic', which is the highest value, the game is gorgeous. The view of the island itself is magnificent and the lighting in-game makes the entire game seem somehow enchanted and magical.Storyline: The storyline is pretty simplistic and one should not expect a complex and in-depth storyline from this game. The plot itself is that you are Lili, a botanist and student sent to the supposedly 'uninhabited' island of Geos to collect samples of flowers to bring back home for your research project. However, you find that the island is not empty and that there are creatures (constructs and spirits and many others) of a different variety. Gameplay: As you read in the upper section that Lili is a botanist, you may assume that you will pick flowers throughout the game. Yes, you are correct! You will be picking countless of flowers, breaking vases, talking to goofy individuals, scaring birds, finding items, and fighting spirits (yes, you will pick the flowers off of their backs!). You should not expect a hack-and-slash style or a difficult puzzle from this game.Humor: This game is hilarious. If you actually take your time (like I did) and talk to everyone and read everything, it turns out that our heroine is a gamer! And there are Zelda and Super Mario references (and many more) throughout the game as well as things and topics that would be considered 'inappropriate' are slightly implied so that if your children are playing it, they will not understand. If you are playing it (an adult), you will laugh your butt off!Overall, I truly enjoyed this game. No, it is not difficult but it is hilarious. It is a relatively short game (I would say approximately 3-5 hours if you don't take time to look at anything, read anything at all, explore, or do side quests), and the only reason I have 9 hours game-time is because I wanted to receive every single achievement (and I also kept going afk while in-game). This game is a good way to unwind after playing a scary game or having a bad day. The hilarity of this game is what kept me coming back!

Posted: February 2
												Beautiful graphics and storyline. Some interactions were a little buggy but overall enjoyable to play.

Posted: February 3, 2015
												This is a neat little game. It's very... casual. That certainly is not a bad thing. It's relaxing, easy on the eyes and fun to progress through. The majority of the game consists of walking between four areas, clicking a button next to flowers to harvest them, clicking the same button to kick vases, and occasionally clicking the same button yet again to engage in a minigame where you pull flowers off of spirits. Simple but fun. Where the game really shines though, is in its surprisingly engaging story and characters. This game has some really dark undertones and explores some touchy subjects. Talk to everyone and don't skip the dialogue. I don't really have any major issues with this game. Mostly just insignificant nitpicks, like progression, which requires you to collect red flowers through NPC side quests or through battles with spirits, which isn't a problem in itself, it's just that you don't need a lot to move forward and once you get a couple, you can skip about half the content in the game or do it anyway which essentially accomplishes nothing. It's good that they give a choice of how you can play the game but there's no sense of accomplishment for completing 100% of the game. I don't even think the game keeps track of how many red flowers you get in total. Regardless, I still recommend this game. Twenty dollars does seem a bit pricey but I got a good six hours on my main playthrough and I'll probably return to this game at some point so I'm satisfied.Edit 8/5/15 : Seems the price dropped to ten dollars. It's definitely worth it now if you don't have it yet.

Posted: September 8, 2014
												I've barely put in an hour with the Steam version of this game but I already recommend it. I played Lili as soon as it came out for iOS and in my review of the game then I gave it high marks. I give them again this time around.The best part of Lili for me is that it is full of humor and I actually had a very powerful emotional response to part of the story. It's really that good. But let me pause to point out the one flaw I see in the game.Unfortunately, punctuation is sloppy and visually stands out against such a flawless graphical backdrop. Admittedly, I'm a stickler for quality writing with careful, consistent use of punctuation and spelling as much as an engaging text. Sadly, this is seemingly the only unpolished bit of Lili. Also, while I appreciate the quirky descriptions and tongue-in-cheek collectibles, there is unexpected semi-questionable content for astute readers.That being said, I love the feel of this game so get ready for more gushing. The graphics are stunning with beautiful art direction and an immersive environment. This is even truer in the Steam version. It's funny that it looks as I remember it but then when I checked screenshots from my iPhone playthrough, I realized what time and effort really went into this port. The graphics are redone and gorgeous on the big screen!Lili is a great hero and it's nice to see a nonsexualized female lead. She can be taken seriously and is genuinely likeable. She is also fun to control both on iOS and Steam. I like the control options and found the use of the mouse to give a bit of precision to the main "battle" mechanic of the game. I use quotes because there really are no fights other than plucking plants from the backs of spirits and this unique twist is actually very engaging and serves as both a sort of mini game as well as a well tuned challenge in progression.Finally, I really like the new listings of characters because at the end of the day, they are what made my first experience with Lili so memorable. I look forward to playing through the rest of this game once more and hope you pick it up as well.

Posted: July 1, 2016
												This game must have tons of potential features and online. I love the ambient of this game, soo.. cute and easy to play, even on hardcore difficuties.

Posted: August 24, 2014
												So a rather mixed review, which in itself is odd because I rather loved this game. You play as Lili on an exceptionally child friendly island where you beat the baddies by plucking flowers from their heads, which temporarily ... well I'm not really sure, makes them go off in a huff? They are always available for a rematch if you want to. The island itself is beautiful, the gameplay is reasonable although it very much shows its phone/tablet based roots and the story is charming, although firmly aimed at a younger audience.So what could possibly be wrong with it?Well first up the price. It is a very short game with quite a hefty price tag. I got it as part of a bundle so I'm good, but in general I would not advise paying full price for this unless you really don't need... money.Secondly it advertises itself as two things, one is an RPG. Whilst you have three stats that you can upgrade this doesn't make it an RPG in the sense that most people would understand. The other is the line that references "Zelda, Broken Age, or Psychonauts" all of which I love, but all of which have pretty much no bearing on this game unless it's something along the lines of "if you ripped practically everything out of one of those games and then shortened it massively... then here's Lili!"So yeah... it's a beautiful, short, kid friendly game with lovely visuals, a fun story, funny characters, decent gameplay... but it's overpriced and very misleadingly advertised.Some of the achievements are also a bit hiccup-y with one refusing to trigger, some not counting/triggering correctly, and unfortunately the grindy ones are tied to a single savegame which is a shame because shifting that to a global variable would have made replaying a great option rather than just running round a completed game picking flowers and kicking vases...

Posted: September 17, 2014
												This game is beautiful. From the scenery to the music you can tell the developers put some time into this game. As far as gameplay goes it's kind of reparative. You "fight" the enemies the same way with little variety, and there is only one thing you collect which is flowers. Posted: September 8, 2014
												I've barely put in an hour with the Steam version of this game but I already recommend it. I played Lili as soon as it came out for iOS and in my review of the game then I gave it high marks. I give them again this time around.The best part of Lili for me is that it is full of humor and I actually had a very powerful emotional response to part of the story. It's really that good. But let me pause to point out the one flaw I see in the game.Unfortunately, punctuation is sloppy and visually stands out against such a flawless graphical backdrop. Admittedly, I'm a stickler for quality writing with careful, consistent use of punctuation and spelling as much as an engaging text. Sadly, this is seemingly the only unpolished bit of Lili. Also, while I appreciate the quirky descriptions and tongue-in-cheek collectibles, there is unexpected semi-questionable content for astute readers.That being said, I love the feel of this game so get ready for more gushing. The graphics are stunning with beautiful art direction and an immersive environment. This is even truer in the Steam version. It's funny that it looks as I remember it but then when I checked screenshots from my iPhone playthrough, I realized what time and effort really went into this port. The graphics are redone and gorgeous on the big screen!Lili is a great hero and it's nice to see a nonsexualized female lead. She can be taken seriously and is genuinely likeable. She is also fun to control both on iOS and Steam. I like the control options and found the use of the mouse to give a bit of precision to the main "battle" mechanic of the game. I use quotes because there really are no fights other than plucking plants from the backs of spirits and this unique twist is actually very engaging and serves as both a sort of mini game as well as a well tuned challenge in progression.Finally, I really like the new listings of characters because at the end of the day, they are what made my first experience with Lili so memorable. I look forward to playing through the rest of this game once more and hope you pick it up as well.

Posted: August 24, 2014
												So a rather mixed review, which in itself is odd because I rather loved this game. You play as Lili on an exceptionally child friendly island where you beat the baddies by plucking flowers from their heads, which temporarily ... well I'm not really sure, makes them go off in a huff? They are always available for a rematch if you want to. The island itself is beautiful, the gameplay is reasonable although it very much shows its phone/tablet based roots and the story is charming, although firmly aimed at a younger audience.So what could possibly be wrong with it?Well first up the price. It is a very short game with quite a hefty price tag. I got it as part of a bundle so I'm good, but in general I would not advise paying full price for this unless you really don't need... money.Secondly it advertises itself as two things, one is an RPG. Whilst you have three stats that you can upgrade this doesn't make it an RPG in the sense that most people would understand. The other is the line that references "Zelda, Broken Age, or Psychonauts" all of which I love, but all of which have pretty much no bearing on this game unless it's something along the lines of "if you ripped practically everything out of one of those games and then shortened it massively... then here's Lili!"So yeah... it's a beautiful, short, kid friendly game with lovely visuals, a fun story, funny characters, decent gameplay... but it's overpriced and very misleadingly advertised.Some of the achievements are also a bit hiccup-y with one refusing to trigger, some not counting/triggering correctly, and unfortunately the grindy ones are tied to a single savegame which is a shame because shifting that to a global variable would have made replaying a great option rather than just running round a completed game picking flowers and kicking vases...

												10/10, this game was so great. I loved the unique feel of it, from the stressless enviroment, upbeat music, cute graphics and strange characters. Posted: August 8, 2014
												This is an odd little game!Lili - Child of Geos is an open world adventure with light RPG elements which seems mostly oriented to younger audience. You play part of Lili, quirky graduate who has landed on an island with intelligent humanoid trees and masked "spirit" creatures with the mission of picking up all the rare flowers for her graduation thesis. Problem is, the flowers grow only on spirit's back, so she has to chase them, jump on their back and pluck flowers while they run frantically away. But not to feel bad for the spirits, cause they're all kinda jerks to the tree people who are basically their slaves.It has definitely got my recommendation. Firstly I'll tell what's good about it, then what problems does it have and lastly a conclusion. Pluses:+Graphic. Hands down. They're not exagerating the marketing pitch, the graphic is very nice for such a small, tablet-ported title, nice particle and filter post-proc effects hold on even to AAA modern game standards, and framerate smoothness is commendable. I couldn't manage to lower it under 60FPS anywhere - on rare loading points, on great city panoramas, anywhere! The framerate stayed rock solid stable. +Characters. Tree-people are generally original, are interesting, have charm and personality, and are diverse. Just the way it should be in an imaginative adventure game. Lili is really quirky and charming heroine. A bit simplified characterisation and motivation, which again begs the conclusion this was intended for younger players, but one can see she was written with heart.+Interesting areas. Areas are full of collectibles, small side quests (which usually give cosmetic colectibles) and secrets. It's fun to explore them. Again though, although one can wander around nicely exploring, the areas aren't huge, and can be completely scanned fairly quickly. The game isn't 10s of hours long, more like 4-8h (at the time of writing I had 1.7h registerd and, as I understand other reviews, I'm somewhere around the half mark. On the other hand, the areas are diverse and look lovely all in all.+RPG elements. Although somewhat shallow (4 skill gagues with some 5 stages overall) skill acquiring is a nice touch. Other RPG staple, equippable items is just cosmetic, but is my hat collection is even this early vide and fun to collect. Could have been more deep and flashed out, but better to have it like that than not at all. +Gameplay. As said, exploring the world overall is fun, plucking "minigames" arecahotic when played with mouse, but not too hard with few skill adjustments and prizes are satisfactory. Overall it does it's job well enough, although, yet again is somewhat simple.Now the minuses:-INABILLITY TO CHANGE KEYBINDINGS! I'm a leftie, goshdarnit, and having no possible option to change movement keys to anything other than wasd bothers me alot (if this review were just for me, I'd put here two minuses, 'stead of one). Arrow keys are already used for camera movement (which I already do with the mouse), so they're in the code, I just need an option to change them with wasd, but none exists. Connected to that is -GUI. It seems shody ('seems', not 'is'). It gets the job done, but it's obvious this is a tablet port, the buttons are huge on FHD and some standard shortcuts and usability options don't exist here. Nothing game-breaking, but it could have been better. -Shortness. The game has potential, could have been something much greater, but in it's heart it's a tablet game with tablet shortness. People are reporting around 6h gameplay time. Shame.-+Odd quirks. I... kinda can't describe in detail, but at the moments I'm experiencing strange tonal dissonances in the game. I can't put my finger for whom the game speciffically is. If it's for younger and/or casual audience, then why are there lots of standard gaming touches about modern computer games, and their respectable memes. And rest of the game is depicted like fairytale like fantasy setting. It's not entirely clear how this setting is connected to our world. Lili goes to magical university so 9/10 times I think I'm in fantasysetting, then suddenly the tone shifts to strange and disturbing. Not that I mind, disturbing fairytale has become regular trope in itself (and e.g. I love AM's Alice MR) but it kinda clashes awkwardly. The game doesn't want to commit fully to weirdness, but sprinkles it around in odd bits. It's not a problem, but sticks like a scrapwe on your keyboard you know you'll get used to eventually, but which distracts first 10 times you feel it...-Prize. For such a short game 20€ is a bit much. I bought it within a bundle, so it's definitely worth it, but full prize is a bit too much. Just a bit, but still.Conclusion: Interesting short casual experience with awesome graphic, great exploration and fun story. The game's not a masterpiece, but it doesn't try to be one. I recommend it without a doubt, IF it's on a discount.

Posted: September 20, 2014
												Lili is a joy! The gameplay relies heavily on exploration and finger-puzzle sequences, set in a beautiful dreamworld. Uplifting woodwinds provide an expressive and evocative aural backdrop for Lili's adventure. Lots of nods to other games in the RPG genre. Lili herself is curious, independent, and spits on the infantilization of women in video games (without ever getting too heavy or serious). This game is a delightful fantasy, with pickup & go gameplay - use it as a relaxing respite! I laughed, smiled, and felt generally content while traipsing through Geos.

Posted: November 27, 2015
												Such a precious little gem. It's rather blatantly inspired by the Legend of Zelda (I mean, it even hints to it a few times during gameplay with costumes and jokes and such), but still holds its own. The title character, Lili, is incredibly spunky and all of her wooden friends are hilariously sassy. Posted: September 14, 2016
												First off, I did get this on sale at $5, but I loved it so much I purchased a second copy for my sister.Lili is a wonderful litle game, I gotta say. The art style is fantastic, everything looks so vibrant and full of life. That's actually the main reason I bought it. However, the fantastic scenery isn't the best part. Lili's cast of characters are quirky and unique, all with plenty of soul about them. There wasn't every a single time when I could say I was bored with this game.Now, that being said, the developers did say it was originally going to be a tablet game, and you can tell. While that is by no means a bad thing, it may throw some people off.Another thing is, holy moly, the music is fantastic. Each zone has its own original track that plays throughout that just sounds wonderful, in addition to a few other tracks you'll hear when fighting a boss or entering a room.Each zone is crafted in such a way that is unique from the others, but still fits the over all feel of the game, filled with its own "Constructs" (the wooden robot like inhabitants of Geos) that all have things they need help with, and with malicious spirits that need a good clobbering.One thing I will say, and this may be a negative to some, and a positive to others, but this game is incredibly easy, once you have the controls down. Like I said, it was originally supposed to be a mobile phone/tablet game, so it takes a bit of getting used to on keyboard and mouse, I'm not sure how it feels on controllers. It gets especially easy with the addition of power ups and items.One final thing as well, the game can run very well even on older systems. I purchased a copy for my sister as well as myself, and her gameplay looked identical to mine, and she's using a 9 year old Nvidia GTS250 graphics card and an Intel G3258 processor, and she had no issues at max settings. So, props to the developers for optimizing their game so well.Pros: Fantastic scenery Wonderful OSTFun characters Fun "combat"Cons:Relatively short gamePretty easy, although to some that may not be a bad thing.all in all, for what it is, I love this game and highly recomend it.8/10

Posted: September 18, 2016
												Enjoyable game to while away a lazy Sunday afternoon. Gameplay and story very straight forward. Consists mainly of running around talking to characters to get quests, picking up items, and taking down the 50 Spirit enemies which are found throughout the game. Combat consists of a QTE sequence in which you have to press buttons that pop up on screen, later in the game the QTE's get more difficult. Extremely easy achievements, you can get them all in about 5-6 hours. Works great on Windows 10, supports gamepad though on screen tutorials are not entirely written for someone who is playing with a controller, but this will not stop you enjoying the game. All in all, a good game. Pick it up cheap if you can as once you've finished it, there's not much calling you back to play it again.

Posted: July 17, 2016
												This game is incredibly darker than the games description on the steam store lets on. Assault, kidnapping, attempted murder, cannibalism. Yes, cannibalism. Enemies beg you to stop, pleading to not be violently deflowered. That's right. You violently deflower your enemies from behind. Chasing them down, or sneaking up on them from their blind spots. When you're close enough you'll leap upon them and begin your assault. They'll beg, plead, cry out in pain, even struggle and lash out to shake free from your grasp. And you'll set an actual flashbang off in their face to pacify them while tightening your grasp on your victim. If you do well enough you'll also collect a trophy in the form of their mask they wear, available for you to wear. Showing your next victim they aren't the first and likely won't be the last. When The Mayor stations guards to stop you, a merchant sells you information on where they'll be. This allows you to get the drop on your next victim blocks away from those ordered to protect the people you're assaulting.One of your victims worries their spouse will leave them after you've violently deflowered them. Young, old, male, female. The main character does not discriminate. Eventually assaults the Mayor in the same way, claiming him as yet another notch in the main character's belt. This is some seriously messed up, rapey stuff. And all of this is in the game, including dialog.A game Bill Cosby and Bill Clinton would approve of. At the end of the game main character's father mentions the main character's deceased sibling. At no point in the game are we introduced to this information before then. The fact that the it comes up so very late in the plot can only mean the main character murdered their own sister. The main character is a psychopath, maybe even a drug dealer.Would play again.Total time played: 9.3 hours.Price: 10 USD

Posted: July 7, 2015
												I am sad to say this game was a disappointment to me. I bought it (like many people have) based on the dazzling screenshots and videos on the store page, and because it said it was an RPG. It took about a minute since I booted it up to realize that what I had just bought was in no way an RPG and in no way the game I had paid for. If only the Steam refund system had existed back then.The sad part is that this game is beautiful. Really beautiful. The soundtrack isn't half bad either. Now if only those things could have been combined with a robust combat system, a world larger than 3 subdivisions in a small town and more than just a smattering of a story line then it might have been a runaway hit instead of such a letdown. Seriously, you can beat this thing in 3 hours or less, and all the side quests are nothing but fetch and find quests.I want to like this game, but I just can't bring myself to. It would be great if someday someone made a sequel or reimagining of this game, kept the theme, kept the characters and environment, but totally rebuilt and expanded everything else. It would blow minds. This, however, just blew a hole in my wallet.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												In Lili: Child of Geos; you play an invasive, Lara Croft reject, hippie, feminist lesbian human that trolls the ruins of living wood to deflower teenage spirits for her own personal pleasure. Euphemisms aside (that is honest to God what the game is like), it has really great graphics and simple gameplay with absolutely no violence. It is a friendly atmosphere with some ominous overtones in some of the characters that are described as jerks (hence her inclination to want to deflower them). There are some cracks at "men" in the game with her pretentious misandrist comments which makes her look even more lesbian. Oh, she can wear hats you find. This game is excellent for anyone looking for some not so stressful gameplay, or a young child that is still getting the hang of gaming, but still understands the basic mechanics of controller function and objective navigation. If you see it in a bundle or on sale, get it! Twenty bucks is a little steep, but you would definitely be giving back to the developers that seem to know how to make an applause-worthy game with beautiful visuals.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												One of the best-looking games I have played or even seen. Every graphical aspect really shines brilliantly in this game. The gameplay is simplistic but a whole hell of a lot more fun than yet another fps, or zombie horde, or other such nonsense game. This game actually has new, imaginative gameplay features, even if it is just grabbing flowers off some weirdo's back. The dialogues are pretty funny and the game knows it's space well, and uses it nicely. It may have come from touchpads but the controls are fine, and there are lots of camera options, and the graphics, as stated before, look fantastic. I wouldnt call this RPG at all, there are a few basic skill trees and cosmetic items but nothing I have seen so far really qualifies as rpg. Doesn't matter, it's fun just to be inside of these environs. Highly recommended on sale, or even near full price.

Posted: July 9, 2014
												If you had told me 24 hours ago that a game about deflowering people against their will would be my favorite game of the year, I would slap you upside the head and tell you to go back to your dammned Sword Art Online. Even though the premise is silly, and it tries a little too hard to be a Nintendo game, it's an amazing game. Honestly, I wouldn't expect a game this beautiful with such a unique premise to be a Steam game! It's a bit small, I beat it 100% in a little over 3 hours, and it doesn't start out on a very strong point at all. It would've done better with some sort of intro sequence, instead of throwing you directly into gameplay. I also wish it would've had some platformer elements, or, you know, a jump button. With all of the crates lying around in Split Wood, the kid in me was just dying to hop up on them and see where they lead! I could easily compare this game to a watered down Zelda meets Shadow of Collossus, with some LittleBigPlanet-esque characters and graphics.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												Very nice graphics, the game is beautiful. The game is full of nice jokes and fun characters, though some moments have a darker edge to it, overplayed by the bright surroundings. Great colours, everything is shiny and bright, a joy to look at.Even though the controls with the controller are neither configurable nor actually explained, it works well. Every key binding for the items are displayed for keyboard only which may lead to some item waste as you try and figure out which controller button does which. But control is tight and during the spirit fights the controller buttons are shown correctly.There's no speech in the game, but that - for me - only added to the charm. I felt reminded a lot of the Wind Waker, one of my favourite games as a kid. The inspiration clearly came from that game.Unfortunately, the game is awfully short. You only need 3-4 hours to collect everything and defeat every spirit. The items are not really necessary here - though I only played on normal. And even though the game is so short, the fights with the spirit get a tad repetative near the end. Defeating all 52 of them brings nothing to the game, and almost every fight is the same. And replay value is nigh zero, the story is linear and everything is collectible in the first run.I have enjoyed the game so far but I can't really recommend it for full price. Though the game is beautiful, runs well and has a cute main character, it's just too short. Be sure to grab it on a discount, though.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												Lili: Child of Geos is a beautiful yet very simple game that won't appeal to everybody.As someone who was looking for a change of pace from the average brown, explosion based gritty shooter, Lili: Child of Geos was an amazing pallet cleanser. A nice simple story set on a beautiful island with some really nice stand out characters and an easy yet enjoyable mechanic made for an enjoyable yet short experience that I would recommend to people looking for something a little different.As mentioned above, the graphics in this game are superb, every area is crawling with life and every nook and cranny seems to have been paid a lot of attention. The character models as well are all unique and portray an enjoyable visual style that makes them feel much more alive as characters, even despite not being voiced. The dialogue of the game is light hearted and fun, even going so far as to almost break the fourth wall at times when mentioning some of the games obvious limitations. Sadly, the game isn't voice acted which feels like a slight let down. I feel it could of been the icing on the cake here but as mentioned the dialogue is interesting enough to read through. The actual second to second gameplay involves a lot of fetch quest like objectives and the whole game is very easy, you can complete it to 100% in about 4-6 hours but the gameplay isn't the draw here and sometimes the IOS roots of the game can be seen.  Lili: Child of Geos is an experience more than a challenge, a nice vacation from the stressful and grim games that most of us play a lot and I loved it, here is hoping for a sequel!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												It's simple, it's a collect-a-thon, and it takes place in a lovely, brightly-coloured world. It's also one of the darkest worlds you'll ever set foot in. What first seems harmless and cute turns out to be truly evil, while the evil just gets more sinister. Throughout the game all I did was doom a peaceful and moderately oppressed people to fire, famine, and bloodshed. Truly at the end of this game (if it can even be called a 'game') you will feel nothing more than wicked.If you're looking for a game about being evil, this is it. Just because it's non-violent doesn't mean you're going to finish with a clean conscience. In short, this is the game everyone should get. It teaches valuable life lessons about how much having good intentions matter in the face of actions. It should be part of every school's curriculum.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												Lili: Child of Geos is an adventure game that reminds me of the newer Zelda games.  You go on quests, break pots to get loot, challenge enemies, unlock doors and the character talk in text not voice.  Lili is a less violent version of Zelda because you can't die and the enemies are defeated and not killed.  Instead of swinging a sword you pick flowers off their head.  It sounds like a cheezy game but I had fun playing it and it takes some effort to get through the game.  The graphics are really good and the gameplay is easy.  This game is no match for Zelda but it's a fun adventure none the less.  Great for all ages.  I would like to note that considering this game was originally a mobile app game I'm impressed how well it's made.ProsSimple gameplayGraphicsClean languageNot very long (complete around 5-7 hrs).  If this was a Zelda game that would be bad but for this game it's good.ConsAchievements - most are easy to get but there's one you can't get with one playthrough which I find annoying.  To get all 3 training achievements you have to play through a second time.  You can get 2 out of 3 in a single playthrough.  Also, the game wants you to collect 1,000 flowers and breaking pots.  The flowers one takes time but not hard if you constantly collect them.  The breaking pots one seems to take forever because there's fewer of them and never marked on your map.  By the time I finished the game I only broke around 500/1,000...ugh!  If you're serious about achievements that will take up more than 5-7 hrs to complete the game.  The achievement issue doesn't make the game bad, just annoying.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Lili: Child of Geos is one of the bizarrest games I ever played: an open-world flower picking simulator with a stroke of the RPG-brush.You play Lili, who visits an inhabited island to collect flowers for a school project. But she does not pick these flowers from the fields or gardens, she only picks the ones that grow along the streets and on the monsters.Yes, this game features flower-picking based fighting. You chase a monster and then, during the actual fight, you pluck flowers off the monster. Maybe using the mouse makes it too easy, but I never lost one of these fights.To be fair, this fighting model makes more sense on a touchscreen device. This is not as surprising since earlier editions of Lili: Child of Geos were published for mobile devices. And after all, it seems new and creative to me.But the open world of Lili: Child of Geos offers a bit more than flower picking. You can explore, collect stuff, talk to people and solve sidequests which consist of exploring, collecting stuff and talking to people.Lili: Child of Geos is rather short and small. It took me about three or four hours to do the main quests, all the side quests and get all the nonrespawning collectibles. On a more negative side, this game features no voice acting, only textboxes. So, was Lili: Child of Geos any fun for me? Yes, but not 20€ worth of fun, more like 10€. Conclusion: If you need a tiny charming open-world game for inbetween with an uhmm innovative fighting mechanic and this game is on sale, then give it a try.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												My boyfriend and I played this game together and greatly enjoyed it (overall).Overall rating: 8/10Objectionable Content: Mild? (bordering on 'some'?). There is some "humor" that is questionable both in taste and apropriateness for younger audiences. *See end of review for details, including trigger warnings and warnings for parents.As far as the rest of the game goes, the atmosphere and evironments are absolutely stunning and worthy of screenshots. and the music is varied and well-suited. There is a bit of a Zelda-esque atmosphere which comes as no surprising seeing all the little Zelda references sprinkled throughout the game. It was refreshing to play a game that was not violent, yet still involved "beating the bad guys." So many of the characters you meet are adorable and hilarious, and have succeeded in getting laughs out of both of us. It is worth talking to all of them; they say some of the most ridiculous things. The gameplay centered around a very simple concept: pick flowers, though it was a pleasant surprise to find that it could be still be challenging sometimes. I would easily recommend this game to most of my friends.Pros:+ Fun, non-violent gameplay+ Gorgeous visuals+ World worth exploring (not overwhelming like big sandbox games)+ NPCs worth interacting with+ Nice soundtrackCons:- The aforementioned tasteless jokes (why it is 8/10 and not 10/10. they were pretty gross.)- Unexpected spike in difficulty between areas/levels.- Does not clearly state its save mechanism (it's autosave, btw) and does not indicate what triggers a save- Bit pricey for the length. I wouldn't pay more than ~$12.- No replay value (one achievement needs ~half a 2nd playthrough but that's it.)*There are a small handful of instances in which sexual harassment is normalized or made into a joke. Fortunately, they are few and far between, and most are easy enough to ignore and move past, but I can see a couple of the jokes being potentially triggering - especially since you would not see it coming from a game like this (we were very surprised ourselves). None of these jokes are a big piece of the game, but it's enough to make it not an 100% all-ages friendly game. To be more specific,TRIGGER & PARENT WARNING: Stalking (creepy photos of Lili and her butt in one NPC's place), Sexual harassment (abuse of power/authority), Sexual abuse (1 joke).

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												This game surprised me. I well knew that the game was only a simple game, all it was about was picking up flowers (lol?) and quick time events fights. So I was prepared to a mediocre game with a good artistic style.Well, it's much more than that. The style is in fact very pleasant, I would say very well designed levels. You get 5 different levels in which you can free roam (you can't jump so no platforming sessions). Every level is quite different from the other and very suggestive. Every level also comes with its own background music.The 'fights' consist in getting close enough to the enemy, and triggering the QTE (with the mouse cursor, or with ABXY buttons of the 360 controller). It is a nice QTE, compared to the average QTE in other games. During the fight you also can choose whether to use or not some powers (flash bombs).The Character can be upgraded and customized (although the outfits are different almost only in colors). The flower picking is not tedious, comes spontaneous while you walk around enjoying the scenery.When I saw the achievements....picking up 1000 flowers....I thought it was crazy. But no, in fact in only a few hours I did everything in the game and it really was no hassle. I enjoyed every part of it. It is the exact game I was looking for: it is nice, fun enough, and not complicated at all. It is a perfect game for children, or for grownups that want to relax from all the other FPS and action games, and dedicate themselves to this relaxing game. You don't have to reflect, you don't have to plan anything or else, just sit back and enjoy this little game. 80/100

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												I can recommence the game really mutch.Bad Points first tho: The actual Story is pretty short. After 4H of playing im done with the main Story and unlocked every Item, got 3 Stars on every possible Enemy and completed every single Side-Quest.Now going on with the Good Points: I like the graphics very mutch, not too realistic with a little cartoony,handdrawn look. Some good athmosphere Light effects as well as good Bump-Mapping. The Map is just awesome designed and with love to every detail. Also the Character Models are always unique Characters also with effort and creativity put into everyone (except the Spirits, they always look the same, just the Mask differs), while you gotta say that those squeky voices kinda annoyed after a while. Also the Main Character, Lili, has a well thought-out character and a athmosphere fitting look. The Gameplay Mechanics are also something new and nice to experience aswell as they are easy to learn. I've got to mention the Controller Support the Devs put into the game ( you dont run across that often) is also a good job and easy to work with. Also the text lines are always fitting, sometimes funny, and very entertaining ( some spelling issues in items descriptions :/ ).For especially the the Offer Price its totaly worth its money.Before you go, always remember that there are TONS of video Game references or direct Links in the whole game. Try to find and understand them all ;)"It's dangerous to buy games alone! Take this review!"  ;)

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												It is hard not to like this game simply due to its strong sense of personality, sadly while it has style in abundance the variety of content is simply not there. There is a bit of a plot here but ultimately the desire to return to the game isn't strong enough and the reply value is almost zero.This brings me to the issue of, "Should I recommend this game to others?" That is really a very conditional thing because there is money involved. Had this been a F2P game then I would wholeheartedly recommend it due to the fact that, in short sessions, the game is really very enjoyable and is a pleasure to look at. The visuals and style of the game just scream quality from the rooftops and there is enough tongue-in-cheek humour here to put a smile on even the most cynical of faces. If you enjoy games you will come across such a large number of references to other titles it is almost wrong to call them Easter Eggs since the game is saturated with them rather than having them hidden away. The developers clearly love Legend of Zelda and other Nintendo games because they not only attempted to create an Nintendo-esque art style but they also added music to the game which is clearly inspired by games such as Wind Waker. They achieved that goal with such success that you could drop Mario or Link into the game world and they'd look perfectly at home.Unfortunately when it comes to paying money for this and wanting value for money from your purchase, Child of Geos has very little to offer. It reminds me of something that would work well as a casual game for a rainy afternoon but nothing more, as such I wouldn't recommend this game unless it was on sale for maybe £2-3 at most.What the developers have created here is really something which deserves a sequel though, while they missed the mark on gameplay they have set a new benchmark for style and quality for the visuals, music and presentation for an indie game. I sincerely hope that this isn't the last we'll see of Lili.

												Whether or not this game is to your liking I can't say. However I can tell you about my own breif run in with this game. When I first opened the game it was in some obscure resolution that my screens couldn't comprehend. To later on find the options menu proved to be a difficylt task. As the game appearently was taller than my screen but still thinner. So I had to click around outside of my screen until I got the correct button. From there on things just got even more cryptic. For in regards to screen resolution you do NOT have the choice of 1920*1080. Nor any other that fits. Furthermore, as the final nail in the coffin (for me), this game gives you 4 buttons in regards to mouse speed. Going from Medium, High, Highest and "Tablet"..... The game look good, and for some it will probably also be a fun game. But not for me.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2016
												So somehow my review got lost, whether because of this "upgrade" to the complete edition, or some other reason, either way, here's my thoughts from back when I tried this abomination:Really boring, and not my type of game.First the options menu: It's horrible. Only a few resolution options, a few buttons for graphical options, which are preset according to setting like High, Highest, and so forth. No actual customising available. Keybindings cannot be changed. Basic mouse options of inverting, and mouse sensitivity buttons, rather than a bar or a number. All in all, the options menu needs a lot of work.Game starts off talking to everyone, and walking into building to talk to more people. You can also add to your fun by breaking vases or opening chests. The chests contain items that have really unfunny descriptions. That is basically a recurring facet of this game. Unfunny dialogue, stale descriptions, and flat jokes.During dialogue there is some voice work, but it doesn't match the text. Rather, it's your character saying hello multiple times in a conversation, and the constructs/spirit things making weird sounds.Finally, the character design is pretty bad. The female doesn't have to be attractive, nor have large assets, but I'm going to have to say the haircut is pretty horrid. A tumblrina if you will. The whole look of her is unbecoming to me, other than the outfit, which is passable. I suppose she matches an explorer, although it feels like the designer wanted her to be Lara Croft, just without being attractive in a tradional sense. I suppose the word is, hipster. This is of course subjective, but will this present times inspired look work in the future, should someone find themselves playing it? Does it work in present times? I don't feel her look emphasizes 'geeky girl'. It's different, and I feel emphasizes tumblr, SJW, feminist, things of that sort. I personally don't fall into that camp, and as such, makes me worry that the game is designed by a development group that IS affected by those camps. Politics don't belong in a game, unless directly marketed as such, and creativity marred by such a thing is troubling. From what I played of the game, I don't necessarily think the game itself is an extension of SJW beliefs, but I believe the creation of the character you play as in a physical sense, IS affected by the creators political beliefs. Take that as you will.The world is colorful, and the game is inoffensive, in terms of interactions, but it just seems aimed at a younger audience, or people with easily offended sensibilities. I like a wide range of games, whether shooters, puzzles, rpgs, or some adventure games. I'll even go back to games like legend of zelda, or super mario bros. This game, however, is not my cup of tea, and I cannot recommend it. It lacks depth, and your interactions with the world reflects that. I didn't feel engaged, and more like the game was a chore. Maybe I'll come back in the future, but as things stand, it's too boring to hold my interest.

Posted: January 28, 2015
												Lili: Child of Geos is a game centered around picking flowers. I wish I was exaggerating. 90% percent of all quests, combat, gold-farming, and other typical adventure-game mechanics are all done by... you guessed it, picking flowers. It sounds ridiculous, I'll admit. But somehow, this game did it right.The game is very short, only taking 2-3 hours to complete. If you want to complete all the achievements, I imagine that time would roughly double. The world itself is fairly small, consisting of four adjacent cities with only a handful of NPC's in each, but there are just enough side quests to make the world feel used without bombarding you with "New Objectives".This game presents itself amazingly. The graphics ride that thin line of being cartoony, colorful, and plain while still holding the right amount of detail. One major selling point, for me anyway, is the music. The city background themes range from a Legend of Zelda town theme (SerfSide) to a Disney fanfare (Mill Hill).Speaking of Zelda, the easter eggs in this game are many. Through dialog or by finding collectibles, this game makes reference to Legend of Zelda (I mean just look at the title card), Super Mario, Day Z, Fruit Ninja, and Minecraft, and even goes so far as to break the fourth wall a little bit by poking fun at hipsters, "neckbeards", and even Instagram.Don't go into this game expecting a serious RPG. The gameplay is simple and almost repetitive (it's picking flowers, if you haven't caught on by now). Lili: Child of Geos just wants you to have fun, and in the couple hours it takes you to beat the game, you will.
