Posted: September 19, 2015
												Lili: Child of Geos is a beautiful and relaxing action adventure. When I saw screens of it I first thought this is probably some kind of highly polished hidden object game. What “sold” me was when I discovered you can actually walk this marvellous world.Item hint: Get the Skeleton Key early on as well as the Treasure Map (helps you keep track of chest and find flowers). Boots, bracelets and necklaces seem to have negligible effects when hunting Spirits.+ Beautiful somehow cuddly graphics+ Mostly relaxing atmosphere+ Okay story, hints to a possible prequel+ References+ Moderate length+ Game advises to visit the options menu and asks to automatically determine graphics settings+ Basically no grinding+ Good controls0 Unfortunately no voice acting0 Different camera modes- Some advertising for another BitMonster game- Level cap, making it impossible to max out all skills with the same avatar- Flowers sometimes in places that are simply unreachableI started playing this game in the hope it would provide a counterpoint to Dead Island which had become exhausting and bullseye. After playing like 15 minutes I felt pretty relaxed. The game still has tense moments but all in all it's a pretty tranquil experience.Although the game's world is not too big it has an expansive feel to it, maybe because it looks lived-in or alive.The back story is rather light, maybe owed to the mobile origins of the game. You control Lili who has come to Geos as a Vegi-Magical student from the Gildern Magis College (with a deadline) but is quickly entangled in in the conflicts of a two-class society. Most NPCs have some depth to them which you learn by interacting with them, i.e. fighting the bad ones (Spirits) and talking to the good ones (Constructs). There is usually a reward for exhausting interaction.There are some indicators to a story that happened before so there may be a prequel.A Construct mentions a geophantasmogramist visiting the island before LiliThere is a pair of glasses in the lighthouse that look like Lili'sA letter from Lili's father mentions Lili's lost sisterLili finds a tombstone for a girl named Orchid, who may have been, fitting in with flower-named girls, Lili's sisterThe game's title is “Child of Geos” so Lili is supposedly linked to the islandThe fishes find Lili's eyes (without glasses; the player never sees them) very interesting, alternating between wanting others to see them or Lili to hide themLeft over combThe Constructs are wood-based being making a disturbingly wood-based living in wooden houses with wooden furniture and wooden toilets, even toilet paper and even bringing it to a Soylent Green conclusion.There are a number of pop-references in the game and there is a mock pop-quiz where Lili can show off here extensive knowledge of games.There is also occasional, not too much, advertisement for another game by BitMonster.The game is of moderate length and may take you two evenings to complete. You can explore the world some more after you beat it. There are a number of achievements that may make you play some more and the “max out skill” achievements actually require you to stature at least one additional game – it took me not quite an hour to max out a single stat. Besides that there is almost no grinding.Unfortunately, there is no voice-acting. Instead there are a few generic sounds or words, e.g. “Hello”, and Lili's feelings are well-done by stances and facial expressions.With so many games not actually having any actual options, I found it interesting that the game starts out with advising you to go to the options menu and offers to automatically determine your machine's graphic settings.The controls work fine with the world's topology and are pretty tight with few exceptions. When chasing a Spirit it happened at times that instead of jumping onto them I suddenly found myself in conversation with a Construct or picking a flower because the game decided that was more likely what I wanted. Then you're supposed to collect flowers set around the world but a few of them are simply set in places Lili can never reach, e.g under bridges.There is a number of different camera modes that aren't listed in the games help - I didn't find any use for them. Activated them with keys Insert, Delete, Home, End, PageUp, PageDown, then move around a bit to see their effect.Lili: Child of Geos was a lot of fun and I recommend it. I bought the game as part of a bundle and probably wouldn't buy it for the full price (currently 10 Euros) but wait for 50% off. I'd be delighted  to see another game of this kidney, maybe a sequel or Orchid prequel.

Posted: July 14, 2015
												So, this game. Basically, there are two possibilities: either you want all the achievements, in which case you'll play between 5 to 10 hours and have to start a second save (there is ONE achievement that cannot be finished with one save. But it'll take like half and hour MAX to get it done with the second, so...), or you just want to play the game to the end, which is maybe less than 5 hours. (all this in casual mode)I liked playing this. I had two or three times when Lili got frozen/bugged, but they were resolved with a menu on/off in two seconds. The game is very repetitive, if you want all the achievements (get 1'000 flowers, 1'000 broken vases,...), but those will go much faster if you check the tips section on Steam's page.The characters are interesting. It's nice not to have human characters for once, and the dialogs can be fun in a nonsensical way. For a female character, Lili isn't even written annoyingly (much) which has to be noted, since female characters make so very often me want to slam them into the wall. Guys definitively can't make female character interesting. It's like they can't imagine that they could possibly multi-faceted. Anyway, nice game. Not worth more than the 10 € it is sold at, but fun and beautiful, and easy enough if you only want to play the casual mode (haven't tried normal/hard though)Ah, one thing: you can't change the keys in the option menu, and wasd in azerty keyboard is a pain. So remember to alt + shift your keyboard to an english keyboard before starting (or during the game, since I always forget myself, before launching said game ^_^;; )

Posted: July 27, 2015
												Originally designed for iOS and ported to the PC steam, BitMonster has brought an endearing adventure game, and protagonist. You play a young college girl named Lili who arrives on the island to complete and assignment for her class. Little does Lili know that she will be on a grand adventure to save the Constructs from the evil spirits who inhabit the Geos. The game lacks any classical combat mechanics instead opts to use quick time puzzle events, and exploration to drive the story, and multitudes of side quests. The game is short, but does not over stay its welcome, and has more than enough depth to keep you pushing forward to complete the game and the optional side quests. Where the game lacks is in UI elements. The UI is often cumbersome or just archaic at times in its presentation and having to search through your pets, hats and outfits to find what you want. The other major issue that I ran into while playing the game was sometimes the controller would switch to keyboard and mouse controls and force me to switch out of the game and back in, in order to fix it.

Posted: December 29, 2015
												Lili: Child of Geos is a sweet, family friendly game that reminded me a lot of my gamecube and playstation time.... without the aspect of jumping puzzle. Pros:-no jumping puzzles (i mean yeah, it can be a pain for some....I guess?);-you are looking for flowers;-You can break vases;-You can enter people's house and take stuff in their chest;-You can wear different outfits, hats and have cute (or ugly-cute) pets;-The story is kinda short, so it's not a game with too much content or a story you really HAVE to focus on;-Nice soundtrack in the same vibe as Spyro and Jak games;-LOT of easter eggs. And because you can have a fairy as a pet, wear green,  break vases and ruin people's garden, I'll let you guess which franchise is the most represented in these;-No ennemies. The foes in this are spirits that you jump on to remove flowers from their back. Since you have no health bar, this is a minigame based on time, and you can buy items to make it easier.Cons:-No jumping puzzles, if you wanted this game because it has the style of our childhood video games like spyro, jak or the like....there isn't.-You are looking for A LOT OF FLOWERS. This game is a punisment if you want the achievement of picking 1000 flowers and 1000 vases because there is 1/3 of vase compared to flowers. I spent 2 hours more on this game ONLY to pick flowers, and I am at 500 vases... If you have no patience for trophies, this game will be your doom.-You can break a lot of vases, because at one point, if you want money, they are the only source of coins other than a gambling minigame -The items you find... might have a purpose... well, 5 or so of them do, the rest of the 50 you can ind are here for... I don't know:-NO ENNEMIES. I mean, when you defeated 3 times (I think?) a foe, it disapears, so no more minigame for you, and if you didn't do a 3 star score, no trophy for you. Also, maybe it's a bug, but for me when I press the rematch button....there is no rematch. The Spirit doesn't even show up on the map before I leave and come back. Or maybe it's just made to be this way? In any case, this button didn't work for me :/ Even with all these cons, this is a very good game to play, if you just want to play a game. For me, this is probably gonna be the game I play again to take a break of the others I have played too much.

Posted: March 9, 2016
												There's something about the beautiful character designs, bright and colourful environment, simple yet challenging gameplay, and yes even the collectathon-ing that really makes this game special. The controls are a little clunky and the world feels a little 'UDK template'-ish, but there's a soul to this game that I rarely, rarely see.You get a nice little selection of alternate costumes (mostly colour-swaps), a large selection of hats, and a few companion animals that float along-side you - all aesthetic goodies that serve no purpose, and that's how I'd want it. The dialogue in this game is solidly written, with some memorable characters; one in particular is a veritable stream of game references, which you will also find in hat collection. Will you be donning a plumber's hat, or perhaps a green hood with matching tunic and fairy? It's a little on the nose and slightly out of place, but all in good fun.The game isn't 'huge'. You get four small areas of the island to explore, filled to the brim with unique characters and flower-picking 'combat'. You'll spend a few hours here, deep in the game's universe of wood-sprites and mask-wearing opressors. The only complaint I have about this game is its acheivements. Get ready for the long-haul, because the number of pots to break and flowers to pick requires 3-4 playthrough-lengths of grinding spawn points over and over.In short, I can't recommend this game enough. It's the right balance of simple, fun gameplay, exploration, story, creative design and genuine heart you can't deny.

Posted: March 19, 2016
												I only saw interest in this game for the Legend Of Zelda vibe the advertising image had, thinking it would play like one of those games. Sadly, it doesn't, but the game is riddled with nintendo easter eggs.Lili is a short, story heavy game with beautiful graphics and simple gameplay. Controlling Lili, a teen researching this colourful island for educational purposes, you find the island is full of slave like, wooden built, sentient robot humanoids run by evil spirits (who are in the form of creepy, mask wearing creatures). The plot is simple; stop the spirits and let the robot things be free and happy. When it comes to gameplay, this game can get boring quickly, since there are a small amount of mechanics used to vary the gameplay up. Defeating spirits is fun at first, but after realising the amount of spirits there are to defeat in the game, I couldn't be bothered chasing them and accomplishing repeating quick time events over and over again. Sure, defeating them isn't wasted, as oyu are rewarded with their mask and character biography. Every character has a biography, which is nice, but not all characters are interesting. The main characters you meet in the story are charming, cute and even funny when reading their dialogue.Overall, this game is colourful, happy and relaxing. Don't let the advertising image fool you, as this is far from a LoZ game. Buy this if you want a short, cheery story with a few giggles here and there, or really like to collect stuff.

Posted: December 21, 2015
												I don't really remember when I bought this game but I've been sick the last few days and been trying to find something to kill time so I installed it. Not gonna lie, was not expecting much when Lili's character model loaded on the beach and then walking towards walls pushed me forward. However, I got something that was really fantastic. I really miss this genre of games that were popular in the N64 era, and don't understand why they died out. Basically, you're going around collecting flowers off the heads of "Spirits" which are tyrants of wood people called Contructs in order to further your studies as a ...flowerologist? (they made up some name for it don't remember anymore.) Anyways, if you miss these open world collecting games you'll love this. It could do with a lot of fine tuning, especially with Lili. She doesn't have any idle animation except for her fingers twitching and her clothes/hair are constantly being wind blown even inside buildings. Sometimes they zoom in on her face and she's totally expressionless in the few cutscenes they have and I feel like there's more that could be done with it. Also, I don't like how she halts when she picks up flowers from the ground or breaks pots. Kills the flow and makes collecting even more tedious. Upside, the writing is well done and a lot of the characters are extremely likeable and goofy. I actually had a good laugh at a couple of the Spirits and I don't often when I'm playing games by myself. Constructs can be kind of adorable too but many of them sit around crying about being slaves like it's even that hard on them. You got ping pong, guys. Lighten' up.They don't hide the games influences (Legend of Zelda, Mario, Fruit Ninja are all referenced heavy handedly) so if you enjoy those games you'll have fun.

Posted: June 8, 2016
												Charming and beautiful, with some missteps in gameplay.I don't remember exactly how I got this game (I think there was a Female Protagonists bundle?), so I didn't really know anything about it before it was in my library. I didn't know that it started out as a mobile/tablet game, but it makes sense considering much of the gameplay would probably be more approachable on a touchscreen.You play as Lili, a sort of magic-botanist grad student who has traveled to an island to collect flower specimens. You navigate around a small number of interconnected maps, collecting flowers, smashing clay pots full of coins, and completing minor quests for townspeople. There is growing tension between the masked spirits of the island and their peaceful wooden servants, and your specimen hunt lands you right in the middle of the conflict.While the exploration and character interaction is fun and engaging, the majority of the game seems to focus on one particular minigame, which is sort of a precision flower-plucking game. While clinging to the back of a masked spirit, you must accurately grab sprouting flowers while avoiding traps. The spirit bucks back and forth to create moving targets, and occasionally interrupts your progress with a "frenzy" of traps. This minigame is reasonably fun to play, although I don't think the instructions were very clear. You pick flowers while exploring by simply clicking them; to pick a flower in the minigame you have to click and pull away to uproot it. The more advanced stages get very chaotic, and it's unfortunately very easy to lose track of your cursor with all the bright objects flying across the screen.The biggest issue I have with this minigame is that there are FIFTY separate instances for you to complete, and there's not enough variation between stages to justify more than, say, ten. Add the fact that each instance has a 3-star scoring meter, giving compulsive completionists like me cause to replay them, and it starts to get really grindy. Because of the emphasis on this particular part of the game, I assume this was the core concept that the rest of the game was built around.Also grindy are the optional achievements for plucking flowers and smashing pots, which set the goal at 1000 (!) apiece. The flowers and the coins found in pots both function as types of currency, intended mostly for use in the item shop. The shop doesn't carry much; you can buy stat boosts, consumable items to make the plucking minigame easier, and a map upgrade (which I actually found pretty essential). There's a separate shop that sells single-use keys for locked doors. I don't quite understand why that wasn't just incorporated into the main shop, since the main shop also sells an expensive but reusable skeleton key. There's an achievement for maxing out each of your 3 stats, but for some reason they didn't make it possible to bring your 3rd stat all the way to max, so you can't 100% the game in a single playthrough.The music is charming and pleasant, the designs and palettes are visually appealing, and there are some great particle effects. I had some trouble with the camera (mostly the FOV) when I first started the game, and it made me feel kind of queasy. It didn't help that the first area also has lots of lens flare and water spray, but once I got into town it became manageable. The writing was more clever than I expected, considering how cute and all-ages the game apparently is. I don't mean the plot, although there are some dark touches here and there. The character dialogue and some of the menu descriptions have a lot of character and sometimes give teeny-tiny hints of being sort of not exactly all-ages. It's often self-aware, but never self-congratulatory. As an added bonus, the main character is allowed to be female without the writing needing to rely on "girl" tropes.There are a couple bugs (sometimes the minimap toggles off when you decide to challenge a masked spirit again) and more typos than one would expect from an updated release. When you pass through a loading gate between maps, the camera and music both stutter and it's a bit jarring.I would love to see either a remake or sequel with more areas and a greater emphasis on exploration & collection rather than chasing & plucking. Maybe all the functionless Lore Items need to be redistributed to the correct NPCs, etc., and find more reasons to reuse existing characters and give them more involvement.Overall it's easily worth playing. It's fun and bright and engaging, and for me, the great one-liners make up for the grinding.Soup / 10

												Hello everybody,lets have a look at Lili: Child of Geos.You like brutal action with a variety of hundrets of Weapon and hundrets of different enemies?You wan`t to see pixel blood and kill your Enemies?All right!!!So this game is NOT for you.We have fast clicking action, you have one weapon (Your barely hands) and one Type of Enemies (Spirits).You will see flowers and get them from their Head.Sounds boring, hmm?It is not!!!Lili: Child of Geos is a small pearl in a sea of Sharks. You can control Lili via Mouse and Tastatur and have a free choice of your ways. You follow a main story but have sidequests. Your target is to solve the Islands Problems. You can earn money via collecting Flowers, finding treasure or defeating spirits. For those you have to come near them, jump on their back and in a minigame you must get the flowers from their heads. Sounds simple, should be, but can be harder as you thought.You can also raise your skills, that helps you to get and defeat the spirits. Also you can spend the money in usefull items. Most of the achievements are very easy, some depends on grinding but i think the hardest one ist to defeat all the spirits in the Gold way (You can get Bronze, Silver or Gold, depends on how good you get the flowers from them). I like this game and i have much fun with it. Yes it is short. I`m through after about 5 hours, but i wan`t all the achievements, so i will play on. Thanks to Bitmonster for this little pearl. Would  be nice if you make a second part.Many GreetingsWyvern

Posted: January 28, 2015
												Lili: Child of Geos is a game centered around picking flowers. I wish I was exaggerating. 90% percent of all quests, combat, gold-farming, and other typical adventure-game mechanics are all done by... you guessed it, picking flowers. It sounds ridiculous, I'll admit. But somehow, this game did it right.The game is very short, only taking 2-3 hours to complete. If you want to complete all the achievements, I imagine that time would roughly double. The world itself is fairly small, consisting of four adjacent cities with only a handful of NPC's in each, but there are just enough side quests to make the world feel used without bombarding you with "New Objectives".This game presents itself amazingly. The graphics ride that thin line of being cartoony, colorful, and plain while still holding the right amount of detail. One major selling point, for me anyway, is the music. The city background themes range from a Legend of Zelda town theme (SerfSide) to a Disney fanfare (Mill Hill).Speaking of Zelda, the easter eggs in this game are many. Through dialog or by finding collectibles, this game makes reference to Legend of Zelda (I mean just look at the title card), Super Mario, Day Z, Fruit Ninja, and Minecraft, and even goes so far as to break the fourth wall a little bit by poking fun at hipsters, "neckbeards", and even Instagram.Don't go into this game expecting a serious RPG. The gameplay is simple and almost repetitive (it's picking flowers, if you haven't caught on by now). Lili: Child of Geos just wants you to have fun, and in the couple hours it takes you to beat the game, you will.

TL; DR -Cute game adapted from mobile but not worth the price of admission. StoryYou follow Lili on an expedition where she ends up on a misterious island ruled by an evil mayor. SoundNothing to write home about but the voice acting is kinda cute.OtherThe game is packed with multiple geeky references which give the player a cheeky wink. Posted: May 4, 2015
Score: 7/10Similar GamesAnimal CrossingSummaryLili is out sailing to find the island of Geos which is for whatever reason super rare to find. She finds the island and plans on collecting flower samples from the island. The island consists of wooden constructs and spirits. The constructs are essentially ill treated slaves and only Lili can help because your a human. Thus your goal is finish your school project by grabbing onto the mean spirits and... deflower them. As Lili runs around grabbing and deflowering male/female spirits she also collects things. You can buy stuff at the shop as well. You also level up your grab, stealth, and speed skills.The GoodThe art style is amazingly fun and colorful. The pull flowers mini game is actually quite fun considering how simple it is. The music and characters are quite lovely as well. More then anything this game just has that casual goofy fun vibe going for it.The BadIt doesn't have actual speech in the conversations. It advertises itself as a Legend of Zelda when it play more like a Animal Crossing slash flower picking similulator. I would also say that the game suffers from being to simple. You'll be left feeling that the game could have been a legend of zelda if they would have tried for it. The game tends to shove video game references and trivia down your throat.ConclusionIts a casual fun game. Don't go in expecting a grand 3D platformer because this is just a phone game on steroids.ValueAs beautiful and playful as this game is it really isn't a huge value. I can only suggest paying around $4.

Posted: April 30, 2015
												If I have one thing to say about this game, it's that any Zelda series fan should pick this game up. This game is the dev's love letter to gaming in the '90s. The world is beautiful, the characters quirky, and the entire game will bring a feeling of childhood nostalgia for any Gen X-er. Those with kids who are on their way to be second-generation Hylian adventurers will like Lili. The difficulty is adjustable so both the young ones and parents can enjoy a bit of a challenge. The game is short but never feels grindy, a few acheivements notwithstanding.I played with a 360 controller and the hit detection for collecting items was a bit unforgiving at times, but I'm guessing that isn't the case for keyboard/mousers. That was my only real issue with this game.Personally my favorite part of Lili is its humor. You'll notice a lot of screenshots with other videogames being referenced and also with Lili playing the straightman to a world of silly spirits and constructs. This is also the only game I have ever played where every single house has a toilet. Ironic that it's a game where all the characters are wooden dummies.So a thumbs up from me, and I look forward to any sequels or new games from this team.

Posted: June 18, 2015
												Lili: Child of Geos is a fun game if you are looking for a easy-going, slow-paced experience. There is not a lot of complexity to it so those that are looking for a challenge won't find one here. The story tries to hit some areas that I didn't expect with becoming independent and discovering what it is that Lili wants to do in life but it never becomes something that connects. The parts of Lili that really stick out are things such as the attention to detail as almost every room you walk into is something different. The world is also incredibly charming to run through as you hunt down spirits to pick flowers off of.Overall: If you want an easy game withe simple mechanics this is a game for you, if not then maybe go somewhere else.

												Pros:•Costs less than $4 during a sale.•Reminiscent of LOZ: Wind Waker, even to the point of breaking vases for loot + Link's hat + related items!•Looks pretty on its own, but throw in enough rainbow lens flares and it looks beautiful!•Simple and relaxing.•Tons of dialogue... and I mean TONS.Cons:•Camera control with the mouse is weird and hard to use (probably fine with a controller). You'll adjust to it though.•Not much combat... if you can call it that.----One of the better 3D "platformer" titles available on Steam. It's absurd to think this started out as an iPhone game!

Posted: November 30, 2014
												At its core, the gameplay style of Lili: Child of Geos is a tablet game.  You pluck flowers off your target and the difficulty increases by increasing the required number of flowers needed to be picked and the introduction of dangerous objects that mix in with the object.  If my monitor had touch screen capabilities, I would be playing the game with my fingers.  Despite this simplicity the game is fairly enjoyable because it comes in combination with a fairly enjoyable setting and atmosphere.  If I were to compare it, it would have to be with the atmosphere of the first city you wonder through in JRPG games like Final Fantasy IX and Kingdom Hearts.  It has a joyous, adventerous feel that warms your heart.  Maybe not at full price, but I would certainly recommend this game if you want to play around in a happy setting with surprisingly well polished graphics and lighting.  I feel like this game is worthy enough for the developers to turn this into a series starring Lili in more adventures but with more RPG elements, more puzzle elements, and a larger world.

Posted: June 17, 2015
												First off, Lili: Child of Geos is a very lighthearted game with goofy humor and pleasant atmosphere.  There's not much in terms of combat other than jumping spirits and yanking flowers off of them.  It's a very nice game for relaxation and exploration because the settings are absolutely gorgeous!  Not to mention, the characters can be very quirky and even hint at references to other games such as Legend of Zelda. Posted: January 5, 2015
												Just a nice quick review here.I bought this game because I'm a huge sucker for beautiful looking things. I don't really like casual game- something that isn't stimulating really puts me off. But I can't believe how drawn I am to Lili.The gameplay is very simple- you are on an island collecting flowers for your (school?) project. You have to collect red soul flowers from the islands evil spirits. I admit it does get a bit repetitive after a while. But thats where the beauty of the game comes in. The environments feel so greatly detailed. You can go into some of the houses of the towns folk and you get a pretty detailed look at how they run their lives, pictures on the walls, toilet paper on a tree-stick holder! With every new area I seek out- the more amazed I am of the beauty.This is a short happy game- be prepared to do things over and over with a little bit of rotation. But take your time, explore. Experience the beauty.If I'm ever to get the Occulus- I really want this game to be playable with it. I want to be in this dream world!Pros:ABSOLUTELY BEAUTIFUL GAMENice soundtrackinteresting 'people'Sneaky game refrencesCons:Not a really deep storyEnemies are repetativeVery little voice acting makes it feel like a wall of text sometimesI decided to pick up this gem when it was on sale

Posted: November 2, 2014
												As usual with my reviews, let me start with the TL;DR version for those who don't have time to read a wall of text,"Lilli: Child of Geos" is an astoundingly charming indie game full of colour and character. The gameplay is addictive but can get a bit samey, but, thankfully doesn't overstay it's welcome. While the $20 price tag is a bit high for a 5 hour long game, it's well worth a shot when on sale if you are into casual, colourful experiences.Now for the meat:	Lilli is one charming title. There is so much colour in this game to help make the island of Geos feel alive, making each of the characters you meet another interesting addition to the game. Just starting off this review, if I have to say what this game's strong suit is, it is definitely the art direction it took with aesthetics, I couldn't ask for it any other way.	The gameplay, while somewhat reminiscent of "Zelda" games, lacks any sort of true combat mechanic. Even the game remarks at one point, acknowledging the fact that you will not "kill" anything on this island, even the bad guys. The idea predmoninantly is based around the idea of exploring the town (divided into 4 seperate sections) on the island of Geos. While in each section of the town there are various tasks to be completed: from independant exploration to find treasures, flowers, and pots to smash; to completing quests the various towns people have - most of these ranging in a form of a fetch quest, disappointingly.	The game also features RPG-esque stat building. These stat points are there to help aid you in the core mechanic of the game, which is finding, capturing, and defeating "spirits". This involves using the mouse to click on flowers and plants to pluck from the head of the spirit while trying to maintain your grip on said spirit by not plucking thorny plants or getting hit by...-bomb flowers-....	This mechanic works well enough to do the job, but is certainly not the highlight in quality for this game. The mechanic itself tends to get a bit monotonous after a lengthy playthrough with this game, as well as the 3-star rating system that seems to be unclear as to how to obtain a rank. Often times I found a well executed "plucking" of a Spirit would only reward 2 stars, while other times I was fumbling over thorny plants and mis-clicking, I still got 3 stars.	When it comes to the controls of this game, this is probably the worst part, sadly. There are NO REBINDABLE KEYS. while the game doesn't use a lot of keys to begin with, I had many frustration that the "Interact" and the "mount Spirit" function were mapped to the same key, leading often to me talking to an NPC, rather than mounting the spirit I was chasing. Additionally there is some of the ABSOLUTE WORST mouse acceleration in this game. Even set to the "highest" mouse sensitivity, the game seems to have "camera smoothing" which results in the games camera and character feeling very, very floaty. I figured perhaps a controller would feel more comfortable for this type of thing, but surprisingly it was even more uncomfortable for me to play with a controller than a mouse. This is something that I hope the Developer will fix in later patches. Unfortunately, if you gathered with the 3-star rating system, addictive game play, colourful graphics, and wonky controls: Yes, this game seems to be intended for mobile platforms, and I think is quite a blemish on this game to have to comprimise competent, and proper PC graphics and control settings to aid with the underpowered mobile devices.	Before concluding I would like to mention a HUD bug this game seems to have, which is most apparent on 4:3 panels. This game does not feature proper word wrapping or font-size adjustments. Often text will bleed off of the on-screen button or prompt - this looks unattractive and very amatuerish. 	Additionally I want to make 1 side note: While I am not a professor of law, I think this game borders dangerously close to infringing some copyright, with blatant use of Nintendo IP titles and names, additionally a music track in Mill Hill is dangerously close to a track in the Sims 3. 	Lilli, with it's blemishes aside, is still a fun and addicting game to play. While the price tag is hard to justify for it's 5 hour campaign, if you find it on sale, I can't recommend it enough that you play this game. Give it a go if you want a happy, and very casual experience!

Posted: November 6, 2014
												Lili is a short but sweet game by Bitmonster, inc. It's a wonderful first impression for the studio and I honestly cannot wait for them to release more games. The game reminds me a lot of Zelda and Kingdom Hearts in its design which I enjoyed and I thought the goofy story line was cute as well. The cast will steal your heart by the end of the game and you won't really have a problem with that. There a few different areas on the island to explore which is surprising for such a small game. It's quite fun to unlock all the doors and see what's hiding inside. The combat system is interesting. Instead of hitting them or shooting at them you jump on their backs and steal their flowers. I thought this was a very unique take on fighting systems. Lili is beautifully designed and lots of fun to play though it is only about 8 hours long so I would suggest waiting for it to go on sale. If you're looking to blow off some steam this is certainly your game. One of the best games I've played in a long time! 8/10

Posted: November 29, 2014
												Lili: Child of Geos is a game I'd kept my eye on ever since it first appeared on steam. It's colorful and unique art style and character designs interested me enough to put it on my watchlist. Having had the chance to finally give the game a playthrough I can see it both met my expectations and also took them in a different direction. This isn't your typical RPG by a longshot. You won't really be level grinding or anything like that as there really is no battle mechanic. You play as a botanist and your typical task on the island is to pick flowers. The best flowers happen to grow on the backs of creatures known as spirits. Picking them off their backs as they try to shake you off takes the form of a mini-game. I hadn't known going in that the game was a revisioned port of an iOS game, but it by far feels like one. That isn't a bad thing however as this game is beautiful to look at and the 'battles' can get quite challenging when thorny flowers and bombs are thrown into the mix. The game is also quite charming with a very unique art style I greatly enjoyed.I do have a few issues with the game however, the camera has a bit of a wabble motion to it that is noticeable which can't be turned off in the options. If you easily get motion sick, this may get to you at first as it almost did with me, but as you're moving around it becomes less noticable. The game is also dull in parts and repetitive. Especially at first but once the game gains momentum it becomes far more interesting. The game even has a fairly dark undertone which I enjoyed but doesn't ever drown out it's charming and humerous nature. The writing is a bit odd at times though with occasional typos oddly phrased sentences and punctuation errors that hardly ruin the gameplay. Dialog is easy to read and understand even for children, though item descriptions can use words a bit out of reach for younger players. The game also features an auto-save feature which can get annoying towards the end of the game when you're given two choices. I would have liked to have saved at that point manually to reload later and take the other path instead of having to play through again.All in all, I enjoyed myself while I was playing and genuinely felt myself drawn into the world this game created. This game isn't for everyone and I wouldn't consider it an RPG as it's closer to a modern day point and click adventure. I'd recommend it to ages 10-15, especially to female audiences or Miyazaki anime fans as it has a similar world feel. It won't be a length sit. I finished the game in 5.5 hours, but it does have a branching path towards the end.

												This is a more playful and colorful family friendly game, a welcome change from all the grim and hardcore games on the market today. Posted: April 8, 2015
												Simple game but very beautiful and engaging!  It's rather short, I beat it in less than 6 hours, but I thought it was worth it (although I got it on sale). You mainly pick flowers, kick open containers and explore, but that's all you need. It's a fun quirky game with amusing characters. Half the fun of the game was just looking at it. Where limited game play leaves off, the adorable design picks up the slack. This is definitely a game for those people who love to get to every chest and go through every door. There's some cute hats, masks and outfits to collect too.I have only two cons for the game. First, if you see the cute flying french bulldog in the banner? Apparently they took the dog away for newer buyers of the game. I obviously didn't buy the game just for the dog, but it was still disappointing (and throws the term "complete edition" into question). Second, there were a few loose ends left unresolved, so that feeling of completion was marred a bit by a few unanswered questions. I also got the impression from some of the dialog that this is a sequel to another game, but I don't think it is?Regardless, this is a very well-made game, and I still definitely recommend this game!

Posted: January 15, 2015
												This game tries way too hard to make you love the titular character Lili. She's so sassy you just can't help but like her.This is a goregous game. Ok, I just want that to stand. Every character looks unique and feels real, the water and houses and lighting just makes you want to vomit when you look at pixel games afterwards. The graphics were beyond my expectations, as well as the characters themselves. One of the first conversations I had was with a wood person who promptly started vomiting as he saw Lili's (perfect) face, complaining that he couldn't stand the sight of what a monstrosity she was. It was just so out there and bizarre that I couldn't help but chuckle. This game is hilarious, as well as slightly pervy, (I'm looking at you guy who takes photo of Lili's♥♥♥♥♥and posts it proudly on his shop wall). Music will get stale, as well as the combat, which is either extremely hard if you use a mouse, or extremely easy if you use a controller. (Points for whoever guesses which one I used)(Actually I didn't use either, I was there in real life and experienced it for real). Money isn't a problem, but powerups didn't seem to make much of a difference for me, probably because I was so good. Actually the only powerup I cared about was the speed one. Not because drugs, because I don't do drugs and neither should you, kids, but because it just makes life easier to go fast - Norman J. Grossfeld.

Posted: January 30, 2015
												Lili is a sweet and enjoyable little family game, hampered by a lack of polish and a rather threadbare plot.You play Lili, of course, a young student who arrives on a thought-to-be deserted island in search of flowers.  Once there, you discover that a race of beings called Constructs are working as slaves for vicious little critters called Spirits.  Naturally, you'll battle the Spirits, free the Constructs, do a little soul-searching, and save the day.The gameplay is charming, but fairly limited.  You'll walk around, talk to people, do fetch quests, and fight Spirits in what are essentially QTE mini-games.  You jump on their backs and pluck all of their flowers out, avoiding thorns and shedding bombs as you go.  Defeated Spirits merely run off in a huff; everything is very non-violent and kid appropriate.  There's also a gambling mini-game that is fun for a few spins.Sadly, there isn't much story to tie it all together.  It's clear that the evil Mayor will be the Big Bad from the get-go, so not much mystery there.  Lili's only real drama is whether or not to abandon the Constructs to turn in her project on time, and I doubt anyone will be very confounded on which path to choose.  Lili will also exchange letters with her professor that hint at some deeper family trauma at play, but it's only brought up at the very end of the game and nothing much is said of it.  Exploring that a little further might have added some real heart to the game and made it feel a bit more substantial.Of course, many of the game's shortcomings can be traced to its origins as a smartphone app, with an emphasis on sharp graphics and simplistic gameplay.  Make no mistake, the game is quite beautiful, but the transition from app to Steam product was less than ideal.  The game feels a bit unpolished all over, and the achievements are a total mess - some are bugged, others pop up erroneously, and many are tedious grinds which are completely inessential to clearing the game.  The game was perfectly playable on my end and didn't crash, but the whole thing felt rushed.And yet, with all that said, I'll give the game a mild thumbs up.  It's nice to see a family appropriate game on Steam, especially with a female protagonist.  It looks great, has pleasant tunes, and the writing can be quite funny in places.  You can tell that the adult writers were slipping in a ton of gags to either amuse themselves or any parents nearby.  It all goes down easy and most people will get a few hours of fun out of it.  That said, I got the game for 85% off - I wouldn't pay anything close to the base price of $20 for it.  Something in the $5 range is more appropriate.

Posted: December 8, 2014
												I have mixed feelings about this game.  I thought I was getting a full "Zelda"-like game with a female protagonist and a unique combat mechanism, but this was just "Flower-Picking: The Game," with occasional optional fetch quests.I'm not even sure what demographic this was meant for; the dialogues, humor, and videogame references are older-teenager appropriate, whereas the gameplay is simplified enough for an elementary student to master.  Likewise, The main character looks like she's 15 and acts like she's 12, but is supposed to be a graduate student, and has apparently played every old school videogame on the planet except for Zero Wing... even the other characters in the game couldn't place her age.What I liked about this game:- The visuals and character designs were interesting, creative, and well-crafted.  I really enjoyed the overall look and atmosphere of the game, and the attention to detail of the artists.- The game's frequent references to other videogames and movies, the dark humor, and the sassy side comments.  It was worth it to keep talking to characters and to read all the Mayor's signs.- The balanced learning curve.- The ability to pick up wearable items like ridiculous masks, videogame hats, and flying pets.What was okay:- The core game mechanic of picking flowers off spirits' backs.  While there was an increase in difficulty as the game went on (the introduction of thorns and bombs, the movement patterns of the spirit, the need to score higher combos of non-thorn flowers), there was not enough variation for it to feel appreciably different after about the 8th enemy.  The only real distinguishing factor from that point on was how long of a combo you needed in order to win 3 stars; early enemies only need 8-12 flowers in a row, whereas the final boss takes a chain of 30-40 flowers.  As you can imagine, by the 52nd spirit this minigame had worn out its welcome.- Sometimes you will be able to complete optional side quests instead of fighting, which fall into one of four categories: "find all the hidden things," "visit that place you just visited," "fetch an item from the chest you just opened," or "fight that spirit you just fought"... O.o- Four Hand Monty's "if you are short on cash and don't want to break vases" bonus ball-and-cup minigame.- The oversimplified inventory system that consists of three tiers of armor for each of your three stats, three one-use items that I rarely ever used, two kinds of currency, two levels of keys, a cheater's map, and a bottle that summons butterflies for no reason.  That's it, unless you count the treasure trophies that only exist for flavour.What I didn't like:- Being constantly interrupted by either Mailbox, or the Mayor, or the fish, with long blocks of dialogue that you can't really skip.  I'm all about witty banter and story progression, but considering you need to play through the game twice to get all the achievements, it would have been nice to be able to bypass the excessive chatter.- The big mid-game "choice."  I played through the game a third time, just to see what would happen if I chose the alternate path, and it was totally not worth it.  I was expecting at least a cutscene with the Professor.- The rainbow bird poo.  Seriously?  That needed to be a thing?- The achievements.  Some of them made sense, like the ones for beating the spirits, but some of them were needlessly tedious such as the "break 1000 vases" or "scare 500 birds." Additionally, these achievements are not cumulative across multiple playthroughs, you must break all 1000 vases using the same save file.  There is also one broken achievement for this game: "unlock all doors."  It seems there was a discrepancy between the PC version and other ports, with the PC release only having 22/28 unlockable doors programmed in.  Thus, the achievement cannot be unlocked without manually altering the game code (you can find instructions for this online, but I personally didn't want to risk irreparably damaging my game data just for 100% completion).  [Edit 12/19/14: The broken achievement has been removed from Steam, so you can now get 100% completion!]Overall, I would give this game a 7/10.  I liked the setting and the humor, but the core gameplay and the achievements were tiresome and boring by the end.

Posted: December 21, 2014
												Although I do recommend this title, I do so for specific reasons. Specifically from a design aspect, I find the mechanics to be a fascinating way to have a non-combat oriented game that still proves to be challenging, interesting, and altogether very different.The mechanics are pretty simple as far as a concept goes: you are a student botenist, and are collecting rare plants to study for a report, and thus go to an island. However, when you get there, trickster spirits get in your way and steal whatever flowers you have collected. To get them back, you must ride them like an unbroken bronco, plucking them while trying to hang on. All in all, very different, and definitely worth studying, especially if you have any interest in game design. Outside of this main gameplay trope, shall we say, there's a fair amount to explore in this world, with flowers showing up around every corner, plenty of people with well fleshed out personalities to talk with, and an interesting stat system to learn to make future, more difficult spirits more manageable.Then there are the aesthetics. This game is absolutely gorgeous for the few resources it takes. The textures are well placed and the models are incredible. The animations are so carefully crafted, that it draws you into the magical island you have entered. I haven't found anything that feels out of place, or that jars me from the experience of the game, even with all of the collectable hats you can find for your main character.Now the story is why I recommend this game with caution. Although it is fairly well written, it definitely is aimed towards a target audience that I am just not a part of. I believe this game to be designed with players younger than me in mind, older children into the preteen age. I feel like most children could get something out of this game, although I'm not completely sure how young too young would be for this particular title. However, being in my early 20s, this story simply doesn't compell me personally.Now even with the somewhat childish atmosphere and story, I still found myself truly enjoying the game. It's not my favorite game, by a long shot, but for what it is, it does offer some decent entertainment for when I just want to relax and play a game that reminds me of the titles that got me into gaming almost 20 years ago.

Score: 7/10Similar GamesAnimal CrossingSummaryLili is out sailing to find the island of Geos which is for whatever reason super rare to find. She finds the island and plans on collecting flower samples from the island. The island consists of wooden constructs and spirits. The constructs are essentially ill treated slaves and only Lili can help because your a human. Thus your goal is finish your school project by grabbing onto the mean spirits and... deflower them. As Lili runs around grabbing and deflowering male/female spirits she also collects things. You can buy stuff at the shop as well. You also level up your grab, stealth, and speed skills.The GoodThe art style is amazingly fun and colorful. The pull flowers mini game is actually quite fun considering how simple it is. The music and characters are quite lovely as well. More then anything this game just has that casual goofy fun vibe going for it.The BadIt doesn't have actual speech in the conversations. You'll be left feeling that the game could have been a legend of zelda if they would have tried for it. The game tends to shove video game references and trivia down your throat.ConclusionIts a casual fun game. Don't go in expecting a grand 3D platformer because this is just a phone game on steroids.ValueAs beautiful and playful as this game is it really isn't a huge value. I can only suggest paying around $4.

												beautiful, but way too short. i finished the game in about four hours. i was really disappointed, because i wanted to see more of the island, and meet more of the locals. i walked across a bridge, saw a house surrounded by pine trees, and couldn't wait to get down there, but it had turned out that i couldn't access that area.movement is limited; there are set paths you can take, and you can see some areas you would think you could venture into, but can't. it doesn't feel very open, i never really truly felt like i was exploring (which is funny, because sometimes lili describes herself as an explorer).there's only one boss, at the very end of the game, but he handles exactly the same as every other enemy you've beaten in the game before. defeating him was a little anti-climactic, especially since he's only the mayor, and i expected some more powerful (both politically and in strength) enemies.this game is full of memes and references. some of the enemy profiles will give you a good chortle, as well.the way you need to defeat enemies is unique if you use a mouse and keyboard, but if you use a controller, all battles will solely be quick-time events. i liked how, with a mouse, you actually had to pull flowers out of the ground, but with the controller, you could just press A, and i found that significantly less fulfilling.the story is mediocre.there is no end-game.you cannot max all skills (to my knowledge).there are barely any guides for this game, so it's difficult to find help for anything not related to vanity items.overall, like many of the $10 games on steam, it's only worth buying if you can get it for at least 50% off. if you can't buy it, just go look at some screenshots - you won't be missing anything.

Posted: February 14, 2015
												I think it's best to think of this game as one meant for kids. That's not a bad thing. In fact, I'm glad that kids these days can be introduced to gaming with such charming experiences.That being said, "Lili" isn't exactly non-violent. While the most brutal thing you do is pluck a flower from a tree creature's back, there's a strong sense that the confrontations are very personal. The tree creatures end up being humilliated, though not mutilated."Lili" is charming, pretty, and, surprisingly, funny. The humour here works, in large part because the writer wasn't trying too hard. It's exactly the kind of slightly absurdist affair with affinity for randomness that I remember enjoying a lot back when I was 15.What "Lili" is not is a deep game. The environments are pretty, but they're not "explorable", in the sense that you can look behind a corner and sometimes even find some secret stash, but you won't find this activity very compelling. There's no emergent narrative to it. The game's main collectible and currency, namely flowers, feels like a wasted opportunity. There's only one variety of flower and you never need to do anything specific in order to find them, because they just grow everywhere. I was kind of hoping that I was going to build a collection of unique specimens, but that's not the case.I played this game with mouse and keyboard, and in this configuration it's more difficult than it would be on a tablet. During encounters with the tree creatures, the ones that have flowers growing from their backs, plucking a flower requires a mouse gesture rather than a click. This is fine on its own, but mouse gestures are slower and more awkward than their touch screen counterparts, and the timing doesn't seem to have been adjusted. As a result the minigame feels more difficult than it should be.

Posted: March 19, 2016
												I only saw interest in this game for the Legend Of Zelda vibe the advertising image had, thinking it would play like one of those games. Sadly, it doesn't, but the game is riddled with nintendo easter eggs.Lili is a short, story heavy game with beautiful graphics and simple gameplay. Controlling Lili, a teen researching this colourful island for educational purposes, you find the island is full of slave like, wooden built, sentient robot humanoids run by evil spirits (who are in the form of creepy, mask wearing creatures). The plot is simple; stop the spirits and let the robot things be free and happy. When it comes to gameplay, this game can get boring quickly, since there are a small amount of mechanics used to vary the gameplay up. Defeating spirits is fun at first, but after realising the amount of spirits there are to defeat in the game, I couldn't be bothered chasing them and accomplishing repeating quick time events over and over again. Sure, defeating them isn't wasted, as oyu are rewarded with their mask and character biography. Every character has a biography, which is nice, but not all characters are interesting. The main characters you meet in the story are charming, cute and even funny when reading their dialogue.Overall, this game is colourful, happy and relaxing. Don't let the advertising image fool you, as this is far from a LoZ game. Buy this if you want a short, cheery story with a few giggles here and there, or really like to collect stuff.

Posted: December 21, 2015
												I don't really remember when I bought this game but I've been sick the last few days and been trying to find something to kill time so I installed it. Not gonna lie, was not expecting much when Lili's character model loaded on the beach and then walking towards walls pushed me forward. However, I got something that was really fantastic. I really miss this genre of games that were popular in the N64 era, and don't understand why they died out. Basically, you're going around collecting flowers off the heads of "Spirits" which are tyrants of wood people called Contructs in order to further your studies as a ...flowerologist? (they made up some name for it don't remember anymore.) Anyways, if you miss these open world collecting games you'll love this. It could do with a lot of fine tuning, especially with Lili. She doesn't have any idle animation except for her fingers twitching and her clothes/hair are constantly being wind blown even inside buildings. Sometimes they zoom in on her face and she's totally expressionless in the few cutscenes they have and I feel like there's more that could be done with it. Also, I don't like how she halts when she picks up flowers from the ground or breaks pots. Kills the flow and makes collecting even more tedious. Upside, the writing is well done and a lot of the characters are extremely likeable and goofy. I actually had a good laugh at a couple of the Spirits and I don't often when I'm playing games by myself. Constructs can be kind of adorable too but many of them sit around crying about being slaves like it's even that hard on them. You got ping pong, guys. Lighten' up.They don't hide the games influences (Legend of Zelda, Mario, Fruit Ninja are all referenced heavy handedly) so if you enjoy those games you'll have fun.

Posted: December 29, 2015
												Lili: Child of Geos is a sweet, family friendly game that reminded me a lot of my gamecube and playstation time.... without the aspect of jumping puzzle. Pros:-no jumping puzzles (i mean yeah, it can be a pain for some....I guess?);-you are looking for flowers;-You can break vases;-You can enter people's house and take stuff in their chest;-You can wear different outfits, hats and have cute (or ugly-cute) pets;-The story is kinda short, so it's not a game with too much content or a story you really HAVE to focus on;-Nice soundtrack in the same vibe as Spyro and Jak games;-LOT of easter eggs. And because you can have a fairy as a pet, wear green,  break vases and ruin people's garden, I'll let you guess which franchise is the most represented in these;-No ennemies. The foes in this are spirits that you jump on to remove flowers from their back. Since you have no health bar, this is a minigame based on time, and you can buy items to make it easier.Cons:-No jumping puzzles, if you wanted this game because it has the style of our childhood video games like spyro, jak or the like....there isn't.-You are looking for A LOT OF FLOWERS. This game is a punisment if you want the achievement of picking 1000 flowers and 1000 vases because there is 1/3 of vase compared to flowers. I spent 2 hours more on this game ONLY to pick flowers, and I am at 500 vases... If you have no patience for trophies, this game will be your doom.-You can break a lot of vases, because at one point, if you want money, they are the only source of coins other than a gambling minigame -The items you find... might have a purpose... well, 5 or so of them do, the rest of the 50 you can ind are here for... I don't know:-NO ENNEMIES. I mean, when you defeated 3 times (I think?) a foe, it disapears, so no more minigame for you, and if you didn't do a 3 star score, no trophy for you. Also, maybe it's a bug, but for me when I press the rematch button....there is no rematch. The Spirit doesn't even show up on the map before I leave and come back. Or maybe it's just made to be this way? In any case, this button didn't work for me :/ Even with all these cons, this is a very good game to play, if you just want to play a game. For me, this is probably gonna be the game I play again to take a break of the others I have played too much.

Posted: September 10, 2016
												I finished the game the same day I bought it. The main storyline is fairly short, but quirky and adorable. Each Construct is unique in some way, and I was never bored. The 'fighting' mechanic is unique and interesting, and I found it to be very enjoyable. The soundtrack is absolutely perfect, the visuals blew me away, and even with my crappy 10 year old GC, it ran like a dream on the highest settings.If you are like me, someone who feels compelled to break every pot and whatnot, then you won't find the repetative collecting annoying. Flower picking sim at it's finest, but I enjoyed it. I actually went through and got 3 stars on very single Spirit. The nods to Zelda and the one LOTR reference I thoroughly enjoyed, though I wish the underlying cannabalism story had been touched on more. All in all, this is by far one of the best indie games I have played in a long time. 10/10 would reccomend would play again.

Posted: July 27, 2016
												Lili: Child of Geos is a very short but amazingly fun game. The characters are pretty original, and the gameplay style is something on it's own. The actual story should only take about 2-3 hours, but it's amazingly fun plus there are achievements to hunt for.The story is basically you're a botanist girl going to a strange island to learn about the flowers. While there, you meet these wooden NPCs called Constructs that you befriend. You find out they're enslaved by the spirits, and so you go on a quest to defeat the spirits and free the constructs.The gameplay is mostly simple. It's just find the items or jump on a spirit's back and take their flowers to win. The key element that makes the game enjoyable is how beautiful and crisp all the design is. Everything is in an almost super-HD style and it is really pretty.I don't know if I'd play it for the full 10 dollars, but on sale I got it for 3 and it was worth every penny.

Posted: July 28, 2016
												. There  is nothing  bad  about  Lili  and it  was ok . It has great  visuals and  the sound and music is ok. The writing for the characters  was very good  and this is where the game shines .  This game is a very short  . This is what you do in the game  talk to  constructs  those  are the ones oppressed by the  sperits. Chase the spirits  ( the oppressors ) and pick flowers off there back .  kick pots full of money and open treasure chest with various items in them .   It is a very easy game to complete. But it is a very short game .  If you read the description this was originally  a game played on   smart phones,   Given my play through of   it do I recommend you buy it ?  I would purchase it but at a reduced price .. There is not what I would call full voice acting . Each character has  a sound loop  with various sounds. Given for various printed   answers .But with limited  sounds  and face expression .   Lili  in my opinion does not have a lot of replay value . I would  say playing this game is like watching a very good old Walt Disney cartoon   movie. That you had not seen before. .  but once you see it the first time  you really do not want to be watching it over and over again. Also fair warning I did not have any  problems with this game . But  it seems others have  and according to this  LiLi community thread the developers have  abandoned the game years ago .   http://steamcommunity.com/app/266490/discussions/0/351660338694245476/as with all games look at  lets plays on you tube etc  to form your own opinion  and my recommendation for LiLi is that you  buy it at a reduced price.  Given what it was I think about $3 should be what  should be charged for this game .

Posted: September 4, 2016
												I loved this game for the unique "combat" system and it's hilarious dialogue and beautifuly crafted world. The zones are unique yet themed to match their world perfectly. Posted: September 26, 2016
												A cute and fun adventure game for someone looking for something a little different.Graphics: 10/10. Everything looks absolutely gorgeous.Sounds: 8/10. Solid sound effects, pleasant to listen to and add to the ambience.Music: 10/10. Calm, relaxing, and fits the carefree adventerous spirit of the game.Story: 9/10. A pretty good story overall; I don't want to spoil anything though. The characters have a good bit of personality, and you can find items with random bits of lore attached to them all over.Gameplay: 8/10. A solid core of exploration, and the spirit wrangling minigame is pretty fun. Somewhat gameplay-light, but it fits the game well. My only real complaint is that the white flowers you collect don't really do all that much... you can turn them into keys (rendered obsolete as soon as you get the Skeleton Key, which you can do pretty early), sell them for money, or gamble them for a potentially larger amount of money. I was kind of hoping that they'd do more than that.Overall: 10/10. A short game, but a really fun one.A quick note: While the game is mostly kid-friendly, there are a few moments of subtly racy humor here and there. It's nothing a kid would really get though, so it's probably not a major worry.

Hope there'll be another game in the same universe.Thank you, devs (:

Posted: November 15, 2016
												This game is honestly really, really cute, and quite entertaining at times. The plot is decent, the gameplay is pretty fun, and the world looks absolutely beautiful... but there's one big issue that might be a potential deal-breaker for some people.I have an Alienware 13 with an Intel i7-5500U processor (2.40GHz), an Nvidia 960M GPU with the latest drivers, and 16GB of RAM. When I'm using the game's "Low" graphics setting, I can get only just above 30fps if I stand still and stare at a wall. If I use the game's "Highest" graphics setting and I'm moving a lot or generally trying to play the game, I can easily end up with less than 10fps. (For comparison, my computer can easily and consistently get anywhere from 120-150fps in Portal 2 without even breaking a sweat.) I have no idea if the problem is with the game or my computer (though I'd be very, very surprised if it was the latter), but this definitely needs to be mentioned, and hopefully fixed.Other than that, this game is a great experience and a lot of fun, considering that it's a PC port/expansion of a tablet game. Though I was a bit disappointed when I had to play on the "Low" or "Medium" graphics settings to have a framerate better than "slideshow", I didn't really notice it after a while and was simply able to enjoy the game for what it was.The other thing I'm slightly disappointed by - though in a good way - is that there isn't any way to get the soundtrack! The background music is all really nice and calm for the most part, with simple instrumentation and nice melodies. If there was a $1.99 DLC I'd buy it in a heartbeat.TL;DR: If the very thought of getting less than 60fps makes you want to throw up and/or throw your computer out a window, I wouldn't recommend this game. For everyone else, though, it's definitely worth at least waiting for a sale - this game is really cute and fun, and it's got a pretty decent price for the five or so hours of playtime.

Posted: July 5, 2016
												So I've had my eye on this game for a long time but never got around to buying/playing it since I have almost 600 games. I watched it's Kickstarter since its conception as a tablet/smart phone game. The one thing I really liked about this game was the art style, this was the one thing that drew me to it. I absolutely love the way it looks. And now I'm going to throw in my two cents about this title.Pros:+Game is absolutely gorgeous, great art style, nice textures, some decent graphics, nice use of shaders and shadows especially.+The worlds are very nicely detailed but not too detailed to keep with its somewhat cartoony/realistic style.+Characters are all really nicely detailed, matches the style perfectly.+Writing is very well done, some nice jokes that don't go over your head and just nicely done in general and each character has their own style of dialog. There are a ton of hidden adult jokes in the game, it feels almost like there was a conflict between writers, one was trying to put in all these clever little dirty jokes while the other wanted to keep it clean. And I love it, the jokes and gags are well done and not too silly or too adult. Example: 


Lili: Child of Geos 
A Screenshot of Lili: Child of Geos
By: CheekyChan




+Xbox 360 controller support with two control options, MMO and FPS with keybinding.+Kid friendly for the most part but it's done in a way that it's friendly and interesting for everyone, even adults.+QTE's are fun when they work properly.+This game has hats that are not micro-transactions. You actually...dare I say it...UNLOCK THEM BY PLAYING.+Pets that do absolutely nothing but look cool.+Costumes.+Really well done music, has a Wind Waker vibe.+Get to explore the island after completing the game.Cons:-Very basic game, there's really no depth to this game at all and the gameplay consists of running around, talking to people, doing some very limited side quests and then doing a QTE mini-game to defeat spirits.-Controls are a bit confusing when using a gamepad, I personally use an Xbox 360 controller on 3rd person action games and racing games if I'm able to. Lili has some very confusing ideals for the controller. There is no pressure sensitivity for walking/running. I managed to get her to walk once by slightly pressing the stick to the side but that was it, only once. Controls for items on the UI are still showing keyboard inputs and NOT the X360 buttons. Double tapping A will make her run infinitely which is annoying when trying to click on something. Game auto locks onto items and people, I've had this happen to me a few times when trying to attack spirits and all of a sudden talk to a villager even though the cursor was showing on the spirit and NOT the villager. Also, for some reason while running, if you hold the camera left or right, your character then stays stuck running in the direction you were holding when the camera was first being turned, it's not a big deal but it makes the game feel a little clunky.-QTE mini-game messes up, like a lot. I had the camera go into other characters, buildings and walls constantly during the mini-game. Sometimes the camera would look ABOVE the spirit and my character so I couldn't see anything at all. The QTE controls also mess up. You can press a button too early even though you saw it pop up and sometimes the buttons change around for no reason and a lot of the time the buttons won't show up or show on items you can't do anything with, like all four buttons will be highlighting the sharp weeds on the spirit's back and you have to just wait as a bomb is about to explode. I've had bombs explode because of this issue but I only ever had to retry the spirit fights twice, ever as the QTE's aren't hard, the hardest part is the bugs. I also never used an item during any of the spirit fights. And sometimes during a spirit fight, you'll pluck a flower and it will also trigger pulling a sharp weed as well, it can be very annoying at times.-+Performance issues. The game runs fantastically for me and it looks great 99% of the time, but sometimes it'll just drop to 30-40FPS out of nowhere at the most random times, this happens in a lot of games, but there is literally no reason that a game this small in scale should tax a R9 270 2GB at 1080p, specially when there's no AA going on. This game also lacks a lot of video options, it has no advanced video options and no audio options. So a warning to those with lower specs.-Costumes. This is my biggest gripe in whole with this game, it totes itself as having costumes but every single one aside from the secret costume at the end is just a re-colored version of her original outfit. The secret outfit is nice at first, but then you really get a look at it and it's very poorly put together, there are a lot of sharp angles, her legs are messed up and it's honestly just not that appealing. I really wish there was a costume pack or something with genuinely nice costumes.-Bugged hat. I collected everything on my first run through the game without using any kind of walkthrough because I like to be surprised. Well, I found everything but one hat. The blue bird that you can get as a hat and a pet, I missed the hat, you get it from the cardboard axe dude, I missed it and now I cannot get it again unless I replay the game. That's annoying. I just wanted everything in a single playthrough.-The devs try to push the game as a Legend of Zelda like title, they even have an outfit and pet hinting at the series but it is most definitely not. It doesn't feel like a tablet title as it was born from, but it most certainly doesn't feel like a LoZ like game. And that's not a bad thing, the game is fine and isn't trying to be anything it's not but it's a bit misleading to potential buyers, especially since the art style is clearly inspired by Wind Waker minus the cell-shading.-Game is super short, I beat it in a single sitting of only a few hours and got everything but a few achievements and a single hat that you can’t get if you missed the window to collect it.-Music volume. It is so loud and no way to adjust in the menus, especially right in the beginning. Luckily, it's got some really nice music, sadly, there are very few songs.Ehh's:-Annoyingly long achievements. Almost all the achievements for this game are just okay, I have no problems with them. But there are two I dislike; break 1000 vases and pick 1000 flowers. You'd have to beat the game a grand total of about 12 times if you were just casually smashing vases or picking up flowers and not purposely trying to get the achievement. I just don't have the patience or will power to play such a short game so many times to get two simple achievements specially since it takes a whole two seconds to break a vase when it should be instant for such a grindy achievement.-Hats just don't fit right, they look really strange on Lili, like they're way too big and most of the hats are not very inspiring or "cool". I just feel nothing when I put a new hat on her. Masks are fine, the wings are really nice too, but the hats just do nothing for me.Closing & Other Thoughts:Overall, I really dig this game. It’s not GOTY material or anything and it is a very well done port of a tablet game so don’t expect anything too crazy out of it, but it is a fun exploration game. Just know, you’re playing this game for the story, writing, art, music and characters and not the gameplay itself.The game has some annoying issues that I addressed but ultimately, I still really liked this title and recommend it to anyone who likes exploration, story or puzzle games.

Posted: March 9, 2016
												There's something about the beautiful character designs, bright and colourful environment, simple yet challenging gameplay, and yes even the collectathon-ing that really makes this game special. The controls are a little clunky and the world feels a little 'UDK template'-ish, but there's a soul to this game that I rarely, rarely see.You get a nice little selection of alternate costumes (mostly colour-swaps), a large selection of hats, and a few companion animals that float along-side you - all aesthetic goodies that serve no purpose, and that's how I'd want it. The dialogue in this game is solidly written, with some memorable characters; one in particular is a veritable stream of game references, which you will also find in hat collection. Will you be donning a plumber's hat, or perhaps a green hood with matching tunic and fairy? It's a little on the nose and slightly out of place, but all in good fun.The game isn't 'huge'. You get four small areas of the island to explore, filled to the brim with unique characters and flower-picking 'combat'. You'll spend a few hours here, deep in the game's universe of wood-sprites and mask-wearing opressors. The only complaint I have about this game is its acheivements. Get ready for the long-haul, because the number of pots to break and flowers to pick requires 3-4 playthrough-lengths of grinding spawn points over and over.In short, I can't recommend this game enough. It's the right balance of simple, fun gameplay, exploration, story, creative design and genuine heart you can't deny.

Posted: December 26, 2016
												If you need a break from reality and you like to hit the <PAUSE> Botton on your troubled brain. Lili: Child of Geos is sooo the place to go!I really liked this as a getaway. Maybe it sounds silly but collecting flowers once in a while isn´t a bad throphy to strive for. It´s a simple but nice story with very likeable fairytale like NPCs. To be honest, I´m not one of those players that need high end graphics, so with that being said: I really like the graphics off this game. But there are two Con-Points on my part:1st: The Music is kinda repetitiv and can spoil the overall relaxation (which I found in the game). Luckily it can be turned off.2nd: I have a different understanding of full controller support in a game. It´s not that the game does not tell you straight up the allocations of the controller, thats ok. BUT, the forgott to allocate the <WALK> Botton. ;0)So, after you leveled up your speed, it´s kinda "Running Only".I would recommend the game, not only for kids but also for those who need a break from ..(let´s say) Doom or other more thrilling AAA Games.
